title: 21st century should able imagine life without bbc licence fee
story: Will license fee detector vans become a thing of the past?Lord Hall, the Director-General of the BBC, announced his retirement this week. Speculation about his successor started immediately. Such speculation is based on the out-of-date idea that it matters who holds the job.Once upon a time, the Director-General did matter, for two reasons. The first was that he (always he, not she) exercised real editorial control, and therefore decided what was broadcast. The first Director-General, Sir John Reith, did this hence the phrase â€œReithian valuesâ€. The second reason was that the BBC was so dominant in broadcasting that the person in charge of it was unassailably powerful.Whenever prime ministers got fed up with the BBC, they therefore used their right to appoint the corporationâ€™s Chairman. The Chairman they chose would get rid of the â€œwrongâ€ Director-General and put in the â€œrightâ€ one.Thus the Labour prime minister, Harold Wilson, wearied of his Left-wing former supporter, the Director-General Hugh Greene, and put in as Chairman a former Tory minister, Lord Hill, to edge him out. Thus Margaret Thatcher, furious at the BBCâ€™s anti-Tory bias under the Director-General Alasdair Milne (father of Jeremy Corbynâ€™s lovable lieutenant, Seumas), made Marmaduke Hussey Chairman. In due time, Hussey appointed the highly effective moderniser John Birt as Director-General.Things are different now. The BBC is such a huge bureaucracy that no D-G can give it an editorial character. There are no â€œHallianâ€ values. Nowadays, its executives are entirely ensnared in their own processes. Look at the comical row about its rates of pay for women â€“ for which the BBCâ€™s only solution is spending much more licence-payersâ€™ money.The bigger change is technological, and therefore competitive. Satellite and cable television, deregulation of radio, and then the internet and all its works have meant that you can watch or listen to British media all day, all your life, without ever having to use the BBC.Millions under the age of 40 do exactly that. But if you have any form of live terrestrial television on any device, you must pay the BBC Â£154.50 a year for a TV licence. If you fail to do so, you can be dragged to the magistratesâ€™ court, where you will be fined up to Â£1,000. Nearly 200,000 people, most of them poor, are thus humiliated in court every year.Should the BBC TV licence fee be scrapped pollEven this scale of unjust persecution cannot prevent technological evasion, so the BBCâ€™s revenue is starting to slide. The system looks doomed. Until quite recently, politicians were so scared of being trashed by the BBC that they dared not reform it. Indeed, the modernising project of David Cameronâ€™s leadership was a way of getting kinder coverage from the BBC by seeming less Right-wing. Now alternative technologies, and the victory of Brexit after nearly four years of unremitting BBC opposition, have altered all that.Boris Johnsonâ€™s thumping majority has proved it is possible to win big without having to talk to the BBC on its terms. His party paid no electoral price for defying the traditional BBC invitation to come on and be humiliated. For the first time in the corporationâ€™s century (due in 2022), it will have to get used to the feeling that the Government does not need it.How, then, should the Boris administration treat the BBC? It is being advised to avoid â€œtrench warfareâ€. It is true that the soft Left will try to unite behind the proposition that the BBC is a â€œnational treasureâ€ which the Tories are trying to destroy. Its rhetoric is starting to equate the BBC with the NHS as a sacred cow. There might be some backlash, especially among more educated voters, against Tory â€œphilistinismâ€ and political interference.The danger of braking, however, is greater than that of accelerating. Big bureaucracies always try to win over their critics with soft words â€“ the well-known phenomenon by which ministers â€œgo nativeâ€ among officials. This is already happening. Note the sudden prominence given on the BBC to the late, great Sir Roger Scruton, the Tory thinker whom, in life, it scorned.Donâ€™t be fooled: much better to maintain the Dominic Cummings refusal to take the BBC at its own valuation. It is well worth any governmentâ€™s while to harass the BBC when it lets slip its political views. As a chartered body funded by a compulsory licence fee, it has to take seriously all accusations of bias. And as a body with its own impermeable, uniform, would-be-right-on culture, it is frequently guilty as charged.Indeed, if the Left does try explicitly to turn the BBC into its fortress in the culture wars, that will only confirm what millions know already, that it has been such a fortress for decades. When I say â€œthe Leftâ€, I am not speaking in strictly party terms (though I am sure very few BBC high-ups vote Conservative). I mean the more generalised de haut en bas wokery which treats Greta Thunberg as Joan of Arc and the wider population as prejudiced idiots.At present, BBC News is running items under the title â€œOur Planet Mattersâ€. Of course it matters. One resents the insulting implication that millions of us think it doesnâ€™t. But in what sense is this news? Why are we forever being preached at and ticked off? The long story of the Brexit struggle has shown millions of Leave voters that the BBC despised them, and tried to deny their voice â€“ for example, by weighting almost all panels and audiences on Question Time and Any Questions? against them. To jumble two well-known metaphors, Boris should strike while the iron has entered our souls.When Nick Robinson grilled me on the Today programme a few weeks ago, he warned me against a split society, such as that in the United States, whereÂ no media is shared by people of differing views. My answer was that such a split has already been created here â€“ by the BBC. Of this, the Brexit story is the final proof.In terms of methods, however, it would be foolish â€“ and wrong â€“ for the Government to try to act like some exterior super-editor trying to â€œgagâ€ the BBC. Except in egregious cases, the Governmentâ€™s concern should be not particular programmes, but the system, especially the money.Future of the BBC | The best comment and analysisIn taking its stance, it is rightly looking at the issue from the point of view of the licence-payer. The phrase â€œpoll taxâ€ is an exactly correct description of the licence fee. Like all undifferentiated poll taxes, it bears heaviest on the poorest. And every year, the service has more and more free riders as the rising generation finds ways of not paying.There are two obvious steps to take. The first, already hinted at by the Government, is to decriminalise non-payment, turning it into an ordinary debt without the shame of a criminal court. The second would be to cut the licence fee substantially, say by half. Rather than trying to dictate what programmes should be cut, this would leave the decision to the BBC. For the first time, its â€œwider still and widerâ€ doctrine would have to reverse. Then it would have to make up its mind what mattered, and how to keep it.I do not necessarily disagree that some things on the BBC â€“ notably Radio 3 and 4 â€“ are good for our culture. If they are, ways, such as subscription, can be found of paying for them. But letâ€™s see what the public wants, instead of telling it what it must have.Coronavirus: Fears rise of Chinese cover-up as 56 million in lockdown and hospitals overwhelmedComment: The BBC is panicking at the publicâ€™s rejection of its arrogant Left-liberal worldviewScreen every soldier for PTSD warns former Helmand officer, as charity runs out of fundingÂ Â UK flags could be lowered under cover of darkness as Brussels plans muted Brexit Day eventsSlimmers on 5:2 diet lose twice as much as weight as those trying &#39Paleo&#39Comment: Britain&#39s jobs market is booming... here are some of the more curious new openingsComment: The folly of HS2 is a modern telling of the Seven Deadly SinsComment: Of course Trump should go - but it&#39s the voters who should kick him outÂ Coronavirus infection: everything you need to know about the outbreak from ChinaÂ Coronavirus: hunt for 2,000 travellers who flew from Wuhan to Britain in last fortnightPowerful earthquake hits Turkey, killing 20 and sending panicked residents onto the streetsWuhan woman &#39cheated&#39 coronavirus checks to fly out for Michelin-starred meal in FranceCoronavirus: How China&#39s increasing global power could be influencing global virus responseHugh Laurie: Celebrities who turn down honours are &#39pompous&#39Donald Trump accused of lying about 34 US troops injured in Iran airstrikeScratch &#39n&#39 sniff patch developed to help vegans and vegetarians beat their craving for baconFraudsters in UK are &#39operating with impunity&#39 amid sharp rise in cases, report revealsThree children found dead at house in DublinMinister says railways are built &#39for our children&#39 in strongest hint yet that HS2 will go aheadWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: coronavirus hunt 2000 travellers flew wuhan britain last fortnight
story: The government will contact 2,000 travellers who landed in Britain on direct flights from Wuhan in the last 14 daysPublic health officials have teamed up with Border Force to trace 2,000 airline passengers who flew into Britain from Wuhan, China, in the past fortnight, to check if they are suffering symptoms of coronavirus.In a significant escalation of measures to prevent the deadly virus from spreading in the UK, the government said it would be tracking down those who could have been in the incubation period when they landed, but may have appeared symptomless.Â Flights from Wuhan are currently suspended, but following a meeting of the government's emergency committee, Cobra, the Chief Medical Officer Prof Chris Witty announced that a Public Health hub of seven clinicians will now be established at Heathrow to monitor people coming from other parts of China.The official death toll in China has now risen to 41, with more than 1,300 confirmed cases. One of those killed was a doctor in China's Hubei province.So far, 14 people tested for coronavirus in Britain have been given the all-clear but checks are still ongoing on â€˜a handfulâ€™ of new cases, and an expert at Public Health England (PHE) said it was â€˜highly likelyâ€™ the virus would reach the UK.Â On Friday night, the first cases were confirmed in Europe as three patients were identified in France. Australia also reported its first case last night while Malaysia confirmed three cases.Speaking after Cobra, which was chaired by the Health Secretary Matt Hancock, Prof Witty, said: â€œWe think there's a fair chance we may get some cases over time.â€œOf course this depends on whether this continues for a long time, or whether this turns out to be something which is brought under control relatively quickly.â€œI think we should definitely see this as a marathon, not a sprint we need to have our entire response based on that principle.â€The Department of Health said most people who develop symptoms will get them after leaving the airport and so it was essential they knew what to do if they became ill.Â When asked why no physical tests were carried out on arrivals into the UK from Wuhan, before flights had stopped, Mr Whitty said: Every country does this slightly differently, that's always been the case.â€He said that after a meeting of the Scientific Advisory Group of Experts, it was concluded: The screening would not really provide any appreciable increase in benefit for the UK public.Dr Paul Cosford,Â emeritus medical director for Public Health England (PHE) said: â€œThere are no positive cases in the UK as yet, but we will go on testing and those numbers will of course change,â€ he told Radio 4â€™s Today programme.Â â€œI think it's highly likely that we will have cases in the UK, and of course every so often we do get new infections coming from the animal kingdom such as this one.â€All the people tested in the UK are thought to have visited Wuhan and four out five patients tested in Scotland were from China, Downing Street said. This graphic shows how the virus can spread.Â How the coronavirus spreadsDr Cosford said anyone returning from China who experienced symptoms should avoid â€˜pitching upâ€™ at hospitals or their GP, and instead contact NHS 111.But he said that the majority of people would probably recover if they contracted the virus.The Chinese city of Wuhan is rapidly building a new 1,000-bed hospital to treat victims, while Disneyland Shanghai and parts of the Great Wall of China have been closed to visitors. Starbucks said on Friday that it would close all of its coffee shops in the Hubei province during the New Year holiday.It comes as China expanded severe travel limits to more than 18 cities, corralling at leastÂ 56 million million people in a wide-ranging quarantine as authorities desperately attempt to demonstrate that they are in control of the coronavirus ahead of Lunar New Year celebrations.All 70,000 of Chinaâ€™s cinemas, as well as attractions such as the Shanghai Disneyland and the Beijing stretch of the Great Wall of China, closed their doors.In Wuhan, the city at the epicentre of the outbreak, construction of a brand new 1,000-bed hospital - which the government pledged will be completed within a week - also began, amid concerns about a shortage of beds and equipment.But the virus has continued to spread internationally, with the United States recording a second infection - this time a woman in her 60s in Chicago. Singapore has now confirmed three cases, while Nepal has identified its first and Thailand its fifth.Private school groups are advising their members to consider planning for the possibility that pupils may not be able to travel during upcoming half term holidays in mid-February.A spokesperson for The Girls' Schools Association said â€œWe are monitoring the situation carefully and are advising schools to consider planning for the eventuality that some pupils may not be able to travel home, or may choose not to travel home, for the half term or Easter holidaysâ€.China sends more students to UK fee-paying schools than any other nation, data shows.The World Health Organization (WHO) is still refusing to declare an international public health emergency, which some experts said is â€˜surprising.â€™In the past, the agency has been accused of overreacting to emerging pandemics, such as its response to bird flu in 2009.Dr Stephen Griffin, associate professor at the University of Leeds, said:Â  The proportion of severe cases appears high. My hope is that this is not a decision that we might come to regret.Peter Piot, professor of global health and director at London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, said the outbreak is in a â€˜critical phaseâ€™ in which intensified international collaboration and more resources was crucial.Coronavirus: Fears rise of Chinese cover-up as 56 million in lockdown and hospitals overwhelmedComment: The BBC is panicking at the publicâ€™s rejection of its arrogant Left-liberal worldviewScreen every soldier for PTSD warns former Helmand officer, as charity runs out of fundingÂ Â UK flags could be lowered under cover of darkness as Brussels plans muted Brexit Day eventsSlimmers on 5:2 diet lose twice as much as weight as those trying &#39Paleo&#39Comment: Britain&#39s jobs market is booming... here are some of the more curious new openingsComment: The folly of HS2 is a modern telling of the Seven Deadly SinsComment: Of course Trump should go - title: totalitarian china incapable telling truth virus
story: Openness to science has not translated into openness for ordinary citizens.Beijing has got better at managing disease, but the desire for total control still leaves it exposedThe temples will not hold their fairs, the trains and planes will not run and the new movie releases, from Leap to Chinatown Detective 3, have been cancelled. China must spend this New Year holiday racing to detect and contain a new respiratory disease, the Wuhan coronavirus, which has killed at least 26 people and scientists think has spread to several thousand.There is good news. The virus is not as deadly as SARS. In fact, it is only about 10 times as deadly as seasonal flu, meaning 98 per cent of people who get it will survive (versus 85 per cent for SARS). While this isnâ€™t exactly wonderful, it isnâ€™t apocalyptic either. Crucially, however, China is managing the Wuhan virus very differently from how it managed SARS in 2003.According to Peter Kellam, a virus professor at Imperial College, the most important factor in managing a pandemic is â€œsharingâ€. This is hardly an area in which Chinese authorities have traditionally excelled, but for scientific purposes, both China and international institutions appear to have learned from Beijingâ€™s disastrous attempt to cover up SARS. Scientists across the world have been given access to data like confirmed infection rates and the virusâ€™s genome, allowing the system to gear up quickly, developing diagnostic tests and researching potential drugs. An inspection team from the World Health Organisation visited Wuhan this week and â€œcommendedâ€ Chinese authorities for their handling of the crisis.As so often in China, however, the boundaries of freedom are strictly drawn. Official state media outlets have kept reporting low-key, placing news of the outbreak below reports of Xi Jinpingâ€™s latest marvellous speech. For now, non-state media have had their leash loosened, but they are ever-alert as to when it shortens again. Whether it is air pollution, anti-foreign rage or product contaminations, the pattern is the same. Periods of relative openness are followed by crackdowns before the debate gets â€œout of handâ€.In some ways, a totalitarian regime might be seen as uniquely well-suited for handling a pandemic. Quarantining a zone of some 30 million people, as China is attempting around Wuhan, has never been done elsewhere. Beijingâ€™s desire to build a surveillance network capable of tracking every single inidual always and everywhere sounds like it might be useful in tracing infection. And Westerners are dumbfounded to hear that the cityâ€™s authorities are erecting a new hospital within a week.Human adaptation to threat is not quite so straightforward, however. The desire for total control, and the illusion of having it, can be just as dangerous as it is efficient. On Monday, President Xi issued an edict commanding officials to put â€œsafety and healthâ€ before all other objectives. Unfortunately, when you have built a political culture on lies and censorship, it is difficult to change the habits of a lifetime by decree.There are multiple reports suggesting that Wuhan city authorities leaned heavily on local media and hospitals to stop news of a new virus from spreading in the initial stages, and information is still being tightly controlled. Scientists abroad may well have been inspecting its genome well before locals were given any comprehensive information about the disease.From here, it might seem inconceivable to think that a government can control the spread of domestic news about a major disease outbreak involving a 30-million person quarantine during the busiest travel time of the year. But Beijing is experienced in such matters. In 2008, authorities permitted a cover-up that led to 300,000 babies being poisoned by contaminated milk formula in order to avoid embarrassment ahead of hosting the Olympics. And across the country, the real 20-40 million person death toll of Maoâ€™s great famine, just two generations ago, is still not widely known.Where cover-ups become tricky is when they hit international scrutiny. It was New Zealand that blew the whistle on the poisoned formula scandal, just as it was the international backlash that made the suppression of SARS impossible and therefore highly politically damaging to the Communist Party. Clearly, the party has learned this lesson when it comes to managing disease.Quick spread of CoronavirusDomestically, however, Chinese citizens know full well that they rarely get the full story from their media or government. It might not directly affect medical collaboration abroad, but it undermines the trust needed to manage public responses during a crisis like a pandemic. If the government tells its citizens not to travel, to report suspicious symptoms or to take protective measures, for example, its advice is more likely to be heeded if it does not have a longstanding habit of lying. And in a really deadly epidemic, living under a government that views its peopleâ€™s lives as disposable could rather change the calculus over whether to go and get tested for a suspected infection.More broadly, it is difficult to change ingrained habits in a system riddled with corruption and distrust. New diseases like the Wuhan virus, as well as bird and swine flu, are known to be especially liable to emerge from food systems in which live, wild game mixes freely with concentrated populations, cooking and slaughtering. Officially, trade in wild animals, from delicious-sounding wild duck to the rather less appealing civet cats and pangolins, is strictly controlled in China.In practice, undercover reporters find live specimens of the poor creatures on sale all over the place, like the market from which the Wuhan virus is thought to have originated. Iâ€™ve seen such a sight myself in a Chinese market, though it was about seven years ago: rows of sorry-looking, panting animals in cages or live insects being snapped in half right next to raw meat being prepped for cooking.For now, Chinese media are being given relatively free rein to report on the problem. But how long will it be before they investigate too far up the chain and cross the wrong person â€“ some senior official with an interest in the trade, for example â€“ and the window of freedom closes?Clearly, Chinaâ€™s management of disease has improved enormously in the last 15 years and we are all safer for it. But openness to science has not translated into openness for ordinary citizens. Unfortunately, this capricious boundary means that a society that produced outbreaks like SARS, H7N9 and a live swine flu epidemic that is even now devastating the countryâ€™s pork industry still cannot openly debate the question: â€œHow does this keep happening to us?â€The  values your comments but kindly requests all posts are on topic, constructive and respectful. title: bbc panicking publics rejection arrogant left liberal worldview
story: The crisis of confidence at the BBC is probably the most visible sign of the shift in public opinionThis is nearly over â€“ this weird disconnect between what most of us understand as reality and the world as seen through the eyes of an all pervasive Authority that was apparently appointed (although we never knew by whom) to establish the limits of public discourse. The crisis of confidence at the BBC â€“ and make no mistake, it is a full blown, all alarm bells ringing, catastrophic crisis â€“ is probably the most visible sign of the shift but it is much bigger than this.So bear with me: I promise that the whole column is not going to be about the BBC, even though it is easily the most infuriating and useful exemplar of the problem.But no, what could be about to implode is not just the sublime, unlimited self-regard of the broadcasters. It is nothing less than the whole interlocking set of preconceptions that are so embedded in the consciousness of those who decide what it is acceptable to think that they must ignore or traduce anything that contradicts them.Of course, self-doubt should have begun with the Brexit referendum result but that scarcely slowed them down: if a majority of the country were benighted bigots then it was up to the enlightened ones to lead them out of the darkness. Or to bully them out of it. And believe it or not, a good many of the Enlightened actually believed they had succeeded in this â€“ hence the demand for a second referendum which would allow the masses to repent of their ignorance.Future of the BBC | The best comment and analysisThen came the general election which was, in effect, a second referendum. And that was the end. You could hear the sound of an edifice falling to the ground and smashing into pieces as you watched the television coverage of this cataclysm. It was such a resounding and utterly unexpected repudiation not just of the mindset of the BBC but of virtually all of the broadcast media â€“ and the cultural circles in which their denizens travel â€“ that it will probably be a generation before they recover. If they ever recover.Indeed, we must hope that the vainglorious arrogance never does return. What we want is not another set of sacred tenets which can be enforced with monolithic certainty, but humility: a genuinely liberal regard for differing opinions. But you know all this. Everybody knows it â€“ except apparently the broadcast executives who are now running around in crazy circles like ants whose nest has been demolished.Presumably this sense of mission to enforce a moral doctrine and prescribe its rules to a grateful nation emerged from the post-war period when rationing and rebuilding dominated the countryâ€™s priorities. The most charitable interpretation of this phenomenon is that it began as a belief that it was the duty owed by the educated classes to British working people who had endured terrible deprivations and danger.If you listen to the patronising tone of the many public information pronouncements of the time, this is what you hear: we are going to create a new future with better housing, a fairer distribution of resources, state-run services and comprehensive health and welfare provision. You must trust our judgment in all things: we know better than you what is needed. Which is pretty much exactly the tone that the political descendants of those public policy managers adopt today, only now they are talking about climate change, multiculturalism, economic globalisation and gender identity.Arguably, a good many of the solutions that the Enlightened Benefactors imposed on society even in that earlier incarnation were wrong-headed or dangerously skewed by the political fashions of the time. Were vast council estates really a social improvement on the old Victorian terraces which might have been renovated rather than demolished? Were rationing and the nationalising of public services actually ways of ensuring fairness, or just a handicap to economic recovery?Lord Hall&#039s message to all BBC staffBut at least back then it was plausible to claim that most people in the country bought into those beliefs. The trauma of the war had created a genuine sense of national unanimity. There had probably never been such widespread agreement on priorities and so much willingness to make sacrifices for the general good. If the specific programmes were questionable, they would be challenged only by a small and rather unpopular minority of sceptics.Needless to say, that is not the case with the doctrines being enforced by the great unidentifiable Authority now. Even if you accept that climate change is a fact, you might want to see less shrill alarmism and more attention paid to possible solutions that do not involve pauperising the developing world. (The BBC recently put Sir David Attenboroughâ€™s announcement of imminent climate crisis at the top of its main news bulletins. With great respect to the saintly Sir David, something that he says is not the most important news story of any day.)You may welcome migrants of all colours and backgrounds, and have limitless compassion for the disabled, without wishing to see classic literary texts re-written and programme presentation rotas designed to ensure their visibility. You may sympathise with the problems of sexual minorities but be disturbed by the proportion of attention that is devoted to their demands. In other words, you may be angry and frustrated by the implicit assumption that you and your reservations are beyond the pale.I am sure it is not an accident that adversaries of the official enlightened wisdom are only invited to participate in broadcast debate under the most loaded and disadvantaged circumstances, to be set against a solid phalanx of the upholders of Virtue â€“ which is why so many of us have given up trying. It is really rather difficult to argue with people who think you donâ€™t have a right to exist (quite literally, in the case of Israel).But the truth has finally hit. To adapt a notorious Corbynism, we are the many and they are the few, and it is time we were given our proper place in respectable conversation.The  values your comments but kindly requests all posts are on topic, constructive and respectful. title: hugh laurie celebrities turn honours pompous
story: Hugh Laurie, 60, told Graham Norton he considered rejecting a CBE in 2018 until his son persuaded him otherwiseÂ Â Hugh Laurie has branded celebrities who turn down honours pompous.The star ofÂ BlackadderÂ andÂ HouseÂ and the long-time comic partner of Stephen Fry accepted his own CBE in 2018 for services to drama, an upgrade on his previous OBE.Laurie has confessed that he considered rejecting the most recent honour, before some frank advice from his son persuaded him not to take the path of pomposity.Ken Loach, the filmmaker, has reportedly turned down such honours in the past, along with Jon Snow, the Channel 4 news presenter, and David Bowie, who declined an OBE.After his deliberations Laurie decided against being up himself, and accepted his own award with good grace.The actor and musician believes that honours are simply part of the system in which stars operate, and there is a self-importance to turning them down.He described his thought process onÂ The Graham Norton Show, where he was joined by his Cambridge University contemporary Dame Emma Thompson.I did wonder about the whole meaning of the thing and whether it is something one should be participating in, Laurie said of being approached with the offer of a CBE.But my son came up with something wise, which was that you'd have to be so up yourself to turn it down.It was a very good way of looking at it and there is something vaguely pompous about withdrawing from it, it's just part of the system.He added that despite only having ambitions to row at Cambridge, he ended up doing all this la-di-da stuff,Numerous British luminaries have refused to play along with this aspect of the system, with John Cleese turning down honours and a peerage, and Stephen Hawking declining a knighthood.More traditionalist literary figures often associated with the establishment have also snubbed any additions to their name. title: job share vacant since harry meghan left
story: Princess Eugenie, pictured with Jack Brooksbank, is back on InstagramWorkers of Britain, keep, erm, working â€“ figures released this week revealed that employment is now at a joint all-time high. A record number of women working full-time (youâ€™re welcome) were partly responsible for this boon, though a 0.2 per cent drop in job vacancies was also recorded. The latter of which seems surprising, given the number of high profile gigs up for grabs at the moment. Such as:Prince Harryâ€™s arrival in his new home of Canada on Monday confirmed the Sussexesâ€™ departure from the British bosom and thus an opening for a new royal â€œitâ€ couple. Which Princess Eugenie seems very keen to fill, ending her months-long Instagram hiatus by posting a picture of herself and husband Jack Brooksbank in Buckingham Palace on Thursday.The tenth in line to the throne had been keeping a low profile following allegations surrounding her father, the Duke of York, that served up the unlikely double whammy of sullying both the monarchy and Pizza Express Woking. But the Harry and Meghan-shaped hole proved too golden an opportunity to pass up, with Eugenieâ€™s return to social media a pertinent reminder that a young couple willing to live in their grandmaâ€™s palace in exchange for the odd flash of public engagement is always close at hand.Top contenders in the â€œyou had one jobâ€ stakes are the Gloucester Marathon marshals who, in fairness, did marshal runners along the course â€“ just in the wrong direction. This led to 15 participants in Sundayâ€™s race being wrongly placed â€“ including the winner â€“ and one entrant being disqualified which, though not identifiably down to the marshals, was probably somehow their fault too.The race organisers intend to sue the (unnamed) marshalling firm for an approach that seemed to consist mostly of pointing and hoping for the best, while participants have shared their relief that â€œjustice has prevailed.â€ Itâ€™s certainly put the 2020 Gloucester Cheese Rolling competition on the map. Not that having one will make any odds to the marshals.How to navigate the advent of Netflix, the licence fee furore and underpaying women to the tune of millions? By quitting as BBC Director General, to take the strategy employed by Lord Hall this week.The opening has apparently aroused much interest at No 10, where Boris Johnson and Dominic Cummings are reported to have begun searching for a replacement â€œsympathetic to their aimsâ€. The pair have not identified what it is about the corporation they find so egregious, yet are apparently certain it needs a â€œbig change,â€ which is very specific and actionable advice.Future of the BBC | The best comment and analysisLast month, Cummings revealed his intention to hire â€œmisfits and â€œweirdosâ€ underlings that would eventually make his own role redundant. Was it all a set-up to facilitate his attempts on W1A? Stranger things have happened â€“ not least his wardrobe choices a few days hence of two scarves, one jumper sleeve rolled up to the elbow and a miniature American football in hand. Cummings-era dress down Fridays at New Broadcasting House would be interesting, if nothing else.Sandi Toksvig is stepping down as the host of the Great British Bake Off, a programme in which amateur cooks fondle bread in a tent set to a running commentary of cake-themed pre-watershed smut. Laughing at the words â€œsoggy bottomâ€ for the eight zillionth time appears to have finally lost its allure for Toksvig, who has co-presented the programme since it moved to Channel 4 in 2017. Guesses as to who will replace her have abounded since: will it be Mel and Sue, Bake Offâ€™s original hosts? Meghan Markle, now sheâ€™s able to pursue acting work again? Prince Andrew, given the impression that dough-based encounter in Woking more than two decades ago apparently made? Stay tuned.Designer Jean-Paul Gaultier gave his final catwalk show in Paris this week, bowing out after five decades of couture creations including â€œman skirtsâ€, â€œgranny hairâ€ and Madonnaâ€™s 1990 cone bra. Having released an â€˜80s dance tune, fronted late-night show Eurotrash (which also starred Carla Bruni and Melinda Messenger) and become a leading voice in the fight for men to take up wearing kilts, Gaultierâ€™s departure from fashion will be keenly felt.Gigi Hadid walks the runway during the Jean-Paul Gaultier Haute Couture SpringSummer 2020 showThough given the advent of eco-pressures on designers, perhaps his exit is well timed â€“ nobody wants a recyclable cardboard cone-boob catastrophe on their hands.Girlfriend for Laurence FoxBeing born into an acting dynasty must be awfully dull. This is surely why Laurence Fox has turned his hand to releasing albums (yes, multiple) bemoaning his orce, as well as appearing on Question Time to decry the censorious Britain in which we now live. One can hardly say anything these days, Fox protested, though he managed to squeeze in accusing a member of the audience of racism, criticising a film for featuring a Sikh actor as a WWI soldier and revealing he once ended a relationship because his other half was too â€œwokeâ€. Wonâ€™t someone free Fox from the shackles of our authoritarian state?After the election bloodbath, Jeremy Corbyn called for a â€œperiod of reflectionâ€. Helpfully for absolutely everybody except Labour, that period appeared to have either never begun or ended as soon as Rebecca Long Bailey entered the race to become leader â€“ and was tipped to win.Read more | Labour leadership raceThat fanfare has since subsided, mercifully, with several unions giving their backing to candidates less confused as to whether their surnames contain a hyphen. At least â€œopposition leaderâ€ is now one of those rare things: a role with job security for the foreseeable.The  values your comments but kindly requests all posts are on topic, constructive and respectful. There was of course nothing green about that, given that it spent much of the time coming on when we werenâ€™t even in. And there was plenty that wasnâ€™t comfortable about it, either, since it would often be on when the house was too hot, or not in as we shivered in the cold. (In the end we gave up and mostly turned it off and on manually.)Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesWe have the Nest Thermostat E. (Nest, which is now owned by Google, are probably the most famous of the smart home companies, and the thermostat is probably their most famous product the E supposedly stands for a variety of things including â€œeasyâ€ and â€œenergy-savingâ€, but basically means that itâ€™s the cheaper version.) Tenet marks Nolanâ€™s return to the mind-melting thrills of Inception and, while the plot remains unknown, it seems to focus on a team of heroes who must rewind time to prevent the outbreak of war. Sign us up. (Jacob Stolworthy) Tom Cruise is taking a (short) break from carrying out impossible missions in 2020. Instead, heâ€™ll return to the cockpit for a sequel to the daddy of all Eighties films, Top Gun. Thereâ€™ll surely be an element of â€œteach new dogs old tricksâ€ in the Joseph Kosinski-directed film as Pete â€œMaverickâ€ Mitchell mentors a new generation of US Navy fighter pilots. Weâ€™re hopeful the result will â€“ wait for it â€“ take our breath away. (Jacob Stolworthy) 1319 Barb and Star Go to Vista Del MarItâ€™s not the Bridesmaids sequel everyone begged for nearly a decade ago, but Barb and Star is its spiritual follow-up at least. Kristen Wiig and Annie Mumulo, the women behind the 2011 smash, write and star in this new comedy, playing two best friends who venture out of their small Midwestern community for the very first time. They soon get mixed up in a villainous plot to kill an entire town, while Jamie Dornan and Damon Wayans Jr also star. (Adam White) 1419 The Many Saints of NewarkWhether you like it or not, a film prequel based on The Sopranos is being released in 2020. The presence of David Chase, the HBO showâ€™s creator, goes a long way to abate any concerns fans might have, and itâ€™ll at least be a fine chance to explore the mobstersâ€™s family history. The film is expected to focus on Dickie Moltisanti, the father of Christopher, whose memory loomed large over the series. (Jacob Stolworthy) 1519 Last Night in SohoEdgar Wright is adding â€œpsychological horrorâ€ to his filmmaking repertoire with Last Night in Soho, a neon-soaked thrill ride starring quite the ensemble (Anya Taylor-Joy, Matt Smith, Diana Rigg). The intriguing plot focuses on a young girl for whom â€œtime falls apartâ€ after sheâ€™s somehow transported to the 1960s. It sounds like a cult hit in waiting. (Jacob Stolworthy) The feel-good West End smash is transformed into a feel-good movie, with Richard E Grant, Sarah Lancashire and Sharon Horgan leading the story of a teenage boy who overcomes insecurity by embracing drag. Newcomer Max Harwood portrays the title character. (Adam White) Regardless of whether youâ€™re a keen follower of the Marvel Cinematic Universe or not, The Eternals should pique your interest. Sure, it may be spearheading a brand new phase of Marvel franchises â€“ there really is no end to the studiosâ€™ box office stronghold â€“ but it features what has to be one of the most eclectic casts ever seen in a superhero film: Angelina Jolie, Kit Harington, Kumail Nanjiani, Brian Tyree Henry and Salma Hayek. Colour us intrigued. (Jacob Stolworthy) Alberto E. RodriguezGetty Images for DisneyA remake of David Lynchâ€™s Dune would ordinarily cause our eyeballs to rattle around our sockets, but not when Denis Villeneuveâ€™s in the directorâ€™s chair. So committed to his vision is Warner Bros that they ignored the fact his breathtaking Blade Runner sequel flopped and handed him the keys to a fresh adaptation of Herbert Rossâ€™ novel. He did direct Prisoners, Enemy and Arrival, after all. TimothÃ©e Chalamet and Zendaya head up the cast. (Jacob Stolworthy) Long in the works, Steven Spielbergâ€™s West Side Story looks set to be a festive smash this time next year. Speculated to be closer in spirit to the original Stephen Sondheim musical than the iconic 1961 film, this new version casts Ansel Elgort as Tony and newcomer Rachel Zegler as Maria â€“ the latter, incredibly, beat out more than 30,000 candidates for the role, after submitting an audition video via Twitter. (Adam White)Last year, director Jon Fravreauâ€™s live-action Lion King, which starred a voice cast including Beyonce and Donald Glover, took $1.66bn (Â£1.27bn) at the global box office, while his 2016 Jungle Book adaptation brought $966m (Â£739m).Disney and the wider film industryâ€™s new obsession with remakes has been the subject of fierce debate among critics and fans, many of whom dislike seeing beloved classics being remade.In 2019, it was revealed that Disneyâ€™s remakes have grossed $7bn (Â£5.3bn) over the past decade.Its latest reboot, the highly anticipated live-action adaptation of&nbspMulan,&nbspis scheduled for release on 27 March.The best in film, music, TV &amp radio straight to your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. The bank also hinted that it may relax&nbspits focus on tackling high inflation as it deals with a combination of slowing productivity and an ageing population, as well as the legacy of the financial crisis.â€œAs our economies are undergoing profound changes, it is the time for a strategy review to ensure we deliver on our mandate in the best interest of Europeans,&nbspECB president Christine Lagarde said on Thursday.Interest rates in the eurozone have been close to zero for the past four years as inflation has stayed below the ECBâ€™s 2 per cent target for almost all of the last nine years. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.'It seems likely that the rise kills off the prospect of an imminent rate cut by the Bank of England,' says&nbspIHS Markit&nbspBusinesses in the UK have enjoyed a post-election boost, according to a snapshot survey that could ward off a cut in interest rates next week.Activity expanded in January for the first time in five months and at the fastest rate for more than a year, driven by the sharpest increase in new work since September 2018, the purchasing managers' index (PMI) by IHS Markit showed.The index, which is based on approximately 85 per cent of usual monthly replies, rose to 52.4 in January, from 49.3 in December. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Quoted companies issued 78 profit warnings in the final quarter of last year, taking the annual total to 313The profitability of UK companies has dropped to a 10-year low, according to official figures that came as surveys showed a fall in retail jobs, a surge in profit warnings, a slowdown in pay growth and a fragile outlook in the construction sector.Private sector firmsâ€™ net rate of return dipped to 9.9 per cent in September down from 10.0 per cent three months earlier. This was the lowest since the aftermath of the global financial crisis in the final quarter of 2009 when it hit 9.5 per cent.The fall was driven by a sharp fall in profits in the North Sea oil and gas, that slimmed to 1.3 per cent from 2.3 per cent as the prices of both fuels fell in the third quarter.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesHowever, the drop in profits was witnessed across business with services firms suffering a 0.4 points fall to 15.2 per cent and manufacturers down by a steeper 0.9 points to 11.1 per cent.Earlier this week figures showed the number of firms issuing profits warnings hit a four-year high in the final quarter of last year, according to business advisers EY.Created with Sketch.UK news in pictures Show all 50Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Gabriella Zaghari-Ratcliffe stands next to her father Richard Ratcliffe, the husband of Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe and his mother Barbara, as they address the media in Downing Street following a meeting with Prime Minister Boris JohnsonRosa Connolly takes a close look during a preview of the Tyrannosaurs exhibition at the National Museum of Scotland, EdinburghThe sun sets behind tower cranes and the London skyline in the city financial districtPrince Harry, Duke of Sussex, speaks with Prime Minister Boris Johnson as they attend the UK-Africa Investment Summit at the Intercontinental Hotel in London. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.'Our economies are undergoing profound changes, it is time... to ensure we deliver on our mandate in the best interest of Europeans,'&nbspECB president Christine Lagarde saysThe European Central Bank has launched a strategic review that could see it use monetary policy to&nbsptackle&nbspthe climate emergency. The bank also hinted that it may relax&nbspits focus on tackling high inflation as it deals with a combination of slowing productivity and an ageing population, as well as the legacy of the financial crisis.â€œAs our economies are undergoing profound changes, it is the time for a strategy review to ensure we deliver on our mandate in the best interest of Europeans,&nbspECB president Christine Lagarde said on Thursday.Interest rates in the eurozone have been close to zero for the past four years as inflation has stayed below the ECBâ€™s 2 per cent target for almost all of the last nine years. Savers in countries such as Germany have grown angry at near-zero savings rates.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesShe said that for the first 10 years of the ECBâ€™s life its goal was to fight high levels of inflation. â€œThe financial crisis was the pivotal point at which eventually inflation was too low, so itâ€™s been a reversal of the situation. It requires that we look at the strategy very carefully and how effective we can be.â€The process is expected to conclude by the end of 2020 and Lagarde declined to say if any decisions had been taken. â€œI would not include, exclude or anticipate how we are going to deliver it,â€ she said.Created with Sketch.World news in pictures Show all 50Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.A Chinese police officer wears a protective mask as he stands guard next to an ad before the annual Spring Festival at a Beijing railway station. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Follow here for the latest updates as authorities seek to prevent a global pandemicThe deadly coronavirus has reached Australia and Europe, with France confirming three cases and the UK hunting for some 2,000 people believed to have recently arrived the outbreakâ€™s epicentre in Wuhan.Two doctors in the Chinese city have died while treating patients in the Chinese city â€“ one after contracting the virus and the other reportedly from exhaustion â€“ with 11 in total being treated. Three have been cured.Meanwhile, travel restrictions in nearly 20 cities are affecting more than 50 million people, further subduing Lunar New Year celebrations as would-be revellers opt instead to stay indoors and authorities cancel events across the country, where authorities say 41 people have now died.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesSpread of virus 'accelerating', Xi Jinping warnsInfected patient found to display no outward symptomsTwo doctors die in Wuhan&nbspas death toll risesAustralia and France confirm first casesChina 'sends 450 military medical staff, including Sars and Ebola veterans to Wuhan'&nbspStaff were sent in three teams&nbspby medical universities of the army, navy and air force of the People's Liberation Army, arriving&nbspin Wuhan by military aircraft on Friday night, the official&nbspPeople's Daily&nbspnewspaper said.&nbspThe paper added that of the nearly 1,300 confirmed cases, 237 people were said to be in a critical condition late on Friday.Russia is in talks with China to evacuate citizens from Wuhan, according to the state RIA news agency.&nbspThere are no Russians infected with the new coronavirus, the agency quoted the embassy's press attache in China as saying.&nbspThe country appears to be following the United States' lead, with the Wall Street Journal reporting the US plans to evacuate some 230 citizens and diplomats on a chartered flight, and temporarily close its embassy in the city.China disease control chief allegedly dismisses 'super-spreader' fears&nbspOn Friday, reports emerged of a super-spreader&nbspâ€“ a single patient who had infected 14 members of staff at a Wuhan hospital â€“ fuelling concerns about the virus's ability to rapidly spread.&nbspBut according to China's state news site, Xinhau, the head of the country's&nbspCentre&nbspfor Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), on Saturday dismissed the reports, saying there was no evidence that the one patient was to blame just because he had been transferred between wards multiple times.China facing 'grave situation' Xi Jinping says, announcing measures to combat outbreak&nbspThe country is facing a grave situation where the coronavirus is accelerating its spread, the president&nbsptold an urgent politburo meeting, which took place on the Lunar New Year public holiday.A state&nbspTV report said resources and experts will be concentrated at designated hospitals for treatment of severe cases, with no treatment delayed due to cost, and supplies of materials to Hubei province and its capital Wuhan to be guaranteed.Beijing to indefinitely shut down all inter-province bus services&nbspChina's capital city will stop all inter-province shuttle buses from Sunday in order to curb the outbreak's spread, according to local media. The reports did not say when bus services will be resumed.Xi Jinping is chairing a politburo meeting on how to curb the virus, state television&nbspreports.&nbspThe politburo comprises the country's&nbsp24 most powerful&nbspofficials and oversees&nbspthe Chinese&nbspCommunist Party.&nbsp&nbspBreaking: US 'to evacuate citizens and diplomats from Wuhan'&nbspThe United States is arranging a charter flight on Sunday to bring its citizens and diplomats back from the city at the epicentre of the outbreak, a person familiar with the operation has told&nbspthe Wall Street Journal.The plane, with around 230 people, will carry diplomats from the US&nbspconsulate â€“ which Washington plans to temporarily close â€“ as well as American citizens and their families, the paper reported.&nbspWashington was given approval for the operation from China's foreign ministry and other government agencies following negotiations in recent days.China's New Year celebrations sidelined by virus concerns&nbspFor China's 1.4 billion people, the holiday is the most important and millions travel thousands of miles back to their hometowns to gather with family and friends.&nbspReuters&nbsphas the following report:To control the spread of the virus, authorities closed part of the Great Wall and suspended public transport in many cities, stranding millions.Chinese state television's traditional Lunar New Year extravaganza on Friday paid tribute to the people of Wuhan and to medical staff fighting the coronavirus crisis, urging them on to victory in the battle to defeat the outbreak,&nbspMany events, such as making offerings at temples, wandering around at outdoor festival fairs, and even family reunion dinners at restaurants have been cancelled as public gatherings were discouraged.&nbspYoung people posted on social media appeals to reduce family gatherings or to at least wear masks when greeting one another with New Year's wishes, which is typically seen as disrespectful in the Chinese culture.&nbspIn Wuhan, the most affected city, the mood was nervous.&nbspThere's so much news, so much data, every 10 minutes there's an update, of the co-legislatorsâ€™ objectives, politicians said in a recently published briefing. The voluntary agreements between different industry players have not yielded the desired results.Apple set to release cheaper and smaller iPhone, report saysBut Apple rejected that characterisation, suggesting that phone manufacturers had actually unified around two different ports. All iPhones have used its Lightning cable for nearly a decade, and most new Android phones use USB-C, it pointed out, claiming that this approach does work.Apple is unlikely to license its proprietary Lightning port to other phone manufacturers, meaning that any new EU rule would almost certainly mean the company would be forced to switch to a new port. That would mean Apple customers throwing away their wires and other accessories, the company claimed, which would have a direct negative impact by disrupting the hundreds of millions of active devices and accessories used by our European customers and even more Apple customers worldwide, creating an unprecedented volume of electronic waste and greatly inconveniencing users.Instead, Apple suggested that regulators should&nbspfocus on the other end of the wire, where the charging cable plugs into the power. Unifying those ports would allow users to plug their charging cables into similar ports&nbspâ€“ in hotel rooms or&nbspcafÃ©s, for instance â€“ no matter what plug was on their phone.We do not believe there is a case for regulation given the industry is already moving to the use of&nbspUSB&nbspType-C through a connector or cable assembly, Apple said in its statement. This includes Appleâ€™s&nbspUSB-C&nbsppower adapter which is compatible with all iPhone and&nbspiPad&nbspdevices. This approach is more affordable and convenient for consumers, enables charging for a wide range of portable electronic products, encourages people to re-use their charger and allows for innovation.The Lightning port was introduced in 2012, with the iPhone 5, as a replacement for Apple's old 30-pin connector. Since then it has been used on almost every one of Apple's portable devices, though the recent iPad Pro uses the industry standard USB-C port.Apple gave no firm indication that it would stick with the existing Lightning port in its iPhones. They needed to cook for two hours on the International Space Station, compared with less than 20 minutes on Earth.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThere's still a lot to look into to figure out really what's driving that difference, but definitely a cool result, Mary Murphy, a manager for Texas-based Nanoracks, said this week. Overall, I think it's a pretty awesome first experiment.Nobody&nbspyet knows what they taste like because they were sealed into inidual pouches and packed for&nbspspaceflight. Five frozen raw cookies were already up there.Italian astronaut Luca Parmitano was the master baker in December, radioing down a description as he baked them one by one in the prototype Zero G Oven.SpaceX to send Nasa astronauts to space soon, Elon Musk saysThe first cookie â€” in the oven for 25 minutes at 300 degrees Fahrenheit (149 degrees Celsius) â€” ended up seriously under-baked. He more than doubled the baking time for the next two, and the results were still so-so.The fourth cookie stayed in the oven for two hours, and finally success.So this time, I do see some browning, Parmitano radioed. I can't tell you whether it's cooked all the way or not, but it certainly doesn't look like cookie dough any more.Parmitano cranked the oven up to its maximum 325 degrees F (163 degrees C) for the fifth cookie and baked it for 130 minutes. He reported more success.Additional testing is required to determine whether the three returned cookies are safe to eat.As for aroma, the astronauts could smell the cookies when they removed them from the oven, except for the first.That's the beauty of baking in space, according to former NASA astronaut Mike Massimino. He now teaches at Columbia University and is a paid spokesman for DoubleTree by Hilton. The hotel chain provided the cookie dough, the same kind used for cookies offered to hotel guests. It's offering one of the space-baked cookies to the Smithsonian Institution's National Air and Space Museum for display.The reminder of home, the connection with home, I think, can't be overstated, Massimino said. From my personal experience ... food is pretty important for not just nutrition but also for morale in keeping people connected to their home and their Earth.Eating something other than dehydrated or prepackaged food will be particularly important as astronauts head back to the moon and on to Mars.Nanoracks and Zero G Kitchen, a New York City startup that collaborated with the experiment, are considering more experiments for the orbiting oven and possibly more space appliances. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium....and the films that beat themItâ€™s easy to get caught up in&nbspawards season&nbspexcitement as the Oscars approach â€“ the glitz and glamour of the red carpet generating global talking points, memes and pub chatter for weeks on end.But when itâ€™s really broken down, the Oscars are essentially just a microcosm of Hollywood. Itâ€™s a depressing fact that films directed by previous winners have more chance of being nominated than those directed by newcomers.Because of this, the&nbspbest film in any given year almost never wins the eveningâ€™s most coveted prize â€“ in fact, itâ€™s sometimes&nbspnot even&nbspnominated in the first place.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesOver the decades, there have been countless glaring omissions&nbspâ€“ films that were nominated but were beaten by far inferior films&nbspand classic films&nbspthat failed to secure a single nomination.As the 2020 Oscars approach â€“ a ceremony thatâ€™s fast becoming a two-horse race between a film that actually deserves the top prize (Parasite) and a film that does not (1917) â€“ weâ€™ve run through 20 brilliant films that you would have expected to be a&nbspBest Picture winner, but werenâ€™t.Click through the bellow gallery to see what films made the listCreated with Sketch.Oscars: 21 great films that never won Best Picture Show all 23Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Long revered as one of the greatest films ever made, Orson Welles' debut â€“ a film following newspaper tycoon Charles Foster Kane â€“ was just another nominee back in the day, losing out to How Green Was My Valley. The Searchers may be considered John Ford's greatest film, but it was not treated as such back in the 1950s. In fact, the western starring John Wayne failed to earn a single nomination. Around the World in 80 Days turned out to be more the Academy's cup of tea.Not only did Alfred Hitchcock never win an Oscar (save for his memorial award in 1968), but neither did any of his films â€“ one of which is Vertigo, a classic that won Sight &amp Sound's once-a-decade greatest films of all time poll in 2012. If it had been nominated, it would have faced stiff competition in the form of eventual winner All About Eve.One of the films that kickstarted the New Hollywood Cinema era, The Graduate may have won director Mike Nichols an Oscar, but it ultimately lost out to Norman Jewison's In the Heat of the Night.  Stanley Kubrick's sci-fi classic remains one of the most influential pieces of cinema there is. The Academy didn't agree. The Academy nominated Kubrick for Best Director and awarded the visual effects in favour of considering 2001 for Best Picture (it didn't even get nominated). That year's winner was Oliver!, the musical by Carol Reed.Despite Taxi Driver's failure to win the main award, its nomination in four categories showed the Academy had good intentions. That All the President's Men and Network also lost out to eventual winner Rocky shows that, ultimately, it never really stood a chance.Francis Ford Coppola's ambitious Vietnam War epic Apocalypse Now received a grand total of eight nominations, but only went home with two prizes (for cinematography and sound) losing out to drama Kramer vs. Kramer.Of all the Oscar blows dealt to Martin Scorsese over the decades, none landed harder than Raging Bull losing out to Robert Redford's weepie Ordinary People, an oversight many consider one of the Academy's most egregious.  Another sci-fi classic overlooked by the Oscars was Blade Runner, which didn't even get nominated in the Best Picture category (Gandhi ended up winning). Ridley Scott's The Martian went on to receive seven nominations in 2017 â€“ evidence, perhaps, of the Academy taking responsibility for its past errors.1023 Do the Right Thing (1989)Spike Lee's Do the Right Thing failing to win Best Picture at the 1990 Oscars is one thing â€“ losing out to Driving Miss Daisy is another thing altogether.   Having awarded both The Godfather Part I and The Godfather Part II Best Picture in 1972 and 1974 respectively, the Academy seemed destined to appreciate Martin Scorsese's Goodfellas. But no â€“ Kevin Costner's directorial debut Dances with Wolves was the most appealing choice for voters.New talent on the block Quentin Tarantino's second feature Pulp Fiction won him the coveted Palme d'Or at Cannes in 1994 â€“ a success he failed to match back on home turf. While he won an Original Screenplay Oscar, his film was beaten by Forrest Gump......and it wasn't the only one. Frank Darabont's adaptation of Stephen King's prison-set novella The Shawshank Redemption also fell victim to Robert Zemeckis' Oscar-friendly Forrest Gump. We don't see that film sitting atop the IMDb top 250 though, do we?If Heat was released today, there's no way it wouldn't be a Best Picture frontrunner. That it was completely ignored in favour of Braveheart is a huge travesty.You may think it was remiss of the Academy to shun Fargo, but it did come pretty close to winning, its chances bolstered somewhat by seven nominations and two wins (Actress for Frances McDormand and Original Screenplay for the Coen Brothers). It lost out to The English Patient.Having won Best Director five years previous for Schindler's List, Steven Spielberg was strongly expected to take home the top prizes for his Second World War epic. Cue Shakespeare In Love upsetting everybody.David Fincher's Facebook drama got shunned in favour of British patriotism in an Oscar two-horse race for the ages that ultimately saw The King's Speech crowned winner.1823 We Need to Talk About Kevin (2011)Lynne Ramsay has directed two films that would have been deserving of Best Picture: You Were Never Really Here and this, We Need to Talk About Kevin. It's easy to see why Hollywood was temporarily more charmed by The Artist, but it's clear which film will stand the test of time.It's almost unthinkable to recall that the Coen brothers' Inside Llewyn Davis only scored two Oscar nominations in the cinematography and sound mixing categories, respectively. In the ensuing years, the film has been hailed as one of the greatest of the 2010s, meaning that its no-show at the Oscars will go down as one of the Academy's biggest omissions. Still, it would have had a hard time winning over 12 Years a Slave.For the 2015 Oscars race, you were either team Birdman or team Boyhood. Richard Linklater's labour of love, shot intermittently over 12 years, ultimately failed to win. If there's any justice, Andrea Arnold will one day become an Oscar winner, but in a perfect world, she would have already won for American Honey, a drama deserving of Best Picture if there ever was one.Horror rarely gets recognised at the Oscars, but Get Out is the closest the genre had come in years. Jordan Peele may have taken home the Best Original Screenplay award, but the stars aligned for Guillermo del Toro's fantasy The Shape of Water instead.Roma was strongly expected to become the first ever foreign language film to win Best Picture. title: space astronomy star superluminous supernovae explained brightest universe
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Discovery 'turns upside down what most researchers have believed,' says one of researchersScientists have found the origin of one of the luminous explosions ever seen in the universe.Superluminous&nbspsupernovae are the brightest explosions in the universe.&nbspSN&nbsp2006gy&nbspis one of the most studied, and has become fascinating to researchers who are trying to explain how such luminous explosions could happen.But such phenomena have remained largely unexplained, with astronomers unable to find the reason for their intense brightness. They shine so intensely that they challenge traditional astrophysical models, which have been unable to account for such a bright star.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesNow scientists think they have found the cause of the blazing brightness coming out of&nbspSN&nbsp2006gy. And they hope that it could shed light on where other such superluminous supernovae get their intensity from.The new breakthrough came when researchers discovered that the star gained its intense brightness when a normal supernova crashed into a shell of material that surrounded it.Created with Sketch.Nasa's groundbreaking decade of space exploration: In pictures Show all 10Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Mystic Mountain, a pillar of gas and dust standing at three-light-years tall, bursting with jets of gas flom fledgling stars buried within, was captured by Nasa's Hubble Space Telelscope in February 2010The first ever selfie taken on an alien planet, captured by Nasa's Curiosity Rover in the early days of its mission to explore Mars in 2012Death of a star: This image from Nasa's Chandra X-ray telescope shows the supernova of Tycho, a star in our Milky Way galaxyArrokoth, the most distant object ever explored, pictured here on 1 January 2019 by a camera on Nasa's New Horizons spaceraft at a distance of 4.1 billion miles from EarthAn image of the Large Magellanic Cloud galaxy seen in infrared light by the Herschel Space Observatory in January 2012. They suggested that vast amounts of iron could account for that particular line, as researchers call it â€“ and when they tested that scenario, it worked.Scientists detect â€˜unknownâ€™ burst of gravitational waves in spaceIt became even more exciting when it quickly turned out that very large amounts of iron was needed to make the lines - at least a third of the Sun's mass - which directly ruled out some old scenarios and instead revealed a new one,&nbspsaid Anders Jerkstrand from the Department of Astronomy at Stockholm University.The researchers suggest that before SN 2006gy&nbspbecame what it is today, there was a double star made up of a white dwarf as big as Earth, and a huge hydrogen-rich massive star the size of our solar system. As the bigger star became even bigger, the smaller one was caught up in it and fell in towards the centre.When it got there, the white dwarf exploded into a Type Ia supernova â€“ a normal supernova. That then collided with the envelope surrounding it, creating the giant collision that sent the light streaming across the universe.That a Type Ia supernova appears to be behind SN&nbsp2006gy&nbspturns upside down what most researchers have believed, says Anders&nbspJerkstrand.That a white dwarf can be in close orbit with a massive hydrogen-rich star, and quickly explode upon falling to the centre, gives important new information for the theory of double star evolution and the conditions necessary for a white dwarf to explode.Be inspired with the latest lifestyle trendsEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Quoted companies issued 78 profit warnings in the final quarter of last year, taking the annual total to 313The profitability of UK companies has dropped to a 10-year low, according to official figures that came as surveys showed a fall in retail jobs, a surge in profit warnings, a slowdown in pay growth and a fragile outlook in the construction sector.Private sector firmsâ€™ net rate of return dipped to 9.9 per cent in September down from 10.0 per cent three months earlier. This was the lowest since the aftermath of the global financial crisis in the final quarter of 2009 when it hit 9.5 per cent.The fall was driven by a sharp fall in profits in the North Sea oil and gas, that slimmed to 1.3 per cent from 2.3 per cent as the prices of both fuels fell in the third quarter.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesHowever, the drop in profits was witnessed across business with services firms suffering a 0.4 points fall to 15.2 per cent and manufacturers down by a steeper 0.9 points to 11.1 per cent.Earlier this week figures showed the number of firms issuing profits warnings hit a four-year high in the final quarter of last year, according to business advisers EY.Created with Sketch.UK news in pictures Show all 50Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Gabriella Zaghari-Ratcliffe stands next to her father Richard Ratcliffe, the husband of Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe and his mother Barbara, as they address the media in Downing Street following a meeting with Prime Minister Boris JohnsonRosa Connolly takes a close look during a preview of the Tyrannosaurs exhibition at the National Museum of Scotland, EdinburghThe sun sets behind tower cranes and the London skyline in the city financial districtPrince Harry, Duke of Sussex, speaks with Prime Minister Boris Johnson as they attend the UK-Africa Investment Summit at the Intercontinental Hotel in London. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Photojournalist Paddy Dowling travelled to Senegal, a country torn apart by conflict, and discovered a new generation of empowered women living in a rapidly changing sub-Saharan climateCreated with Sketch.Senegal: Emerging from conflict to fight climate change Show all 20Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Fatou, 30, comes from a family of farmers approximately 20km away from the village of Bousra where she now lives with her son Ibu. Her husband grows rice during the rainy season and the rest of the time performs duties as a marabou (fortune teller). Djifanghor, 27, is a single mother who lives alone in the village of Niaguis with her mother. After her father died in 2008 her eldest brother was forced to work away to protect the family income. Belange, 23, lives in the village of Soutoure, near Kolda. Her parents have always traditionally farmed rice &amp peanut crops but have noticed the rainy season is unstable â€“ sometimes there is more rain and sometimes there is not enough. Elie, 27, along with her family fled Oussouye in the Ziguinchor Region of Senegal in 1998 at the height of the conflict. She recalls stories of how the rebel groups lit fuel around shelters and make-shift homes and those residents who tried to escape were shot. â€œI still hear the crying and screams of those who perished â€¦ that is still what I have in my mindâ€. Dry inlet at Mandina village near Sedhiou. In recent years water reserves where Cattle used to graze the lush grass at the bank has dropped significantly. All that remains are the discarded nets from a once active fishing area for locals, now a vast area of cracked mud and salt crystals.Khady, 32, lives 4km from Ziguinchor. She participated in both the Agricultural Training camp in December 2018 and spent 3 months at the Incubation camp where she learnt how to transform her crops.A dry inlet bed at Mandina near Sedhiou, where cattle once grazed the lush vegetation on the banks â€“ now all that remains are their footprints and hoof marksAlima, 31, says her ancestors have always been farmers: â€œMy mother, my grandmother and my great grandmother all were, but they farmed very differently. They would grow rice, maize and millet only, whereas we are choosing what is easier for us to grow. We can now make more profit than in the past.â€ Cezi, 29, lives in Carounate, near Ziguinchor. Her father was killed in 1995 during the conflict when she was just 4 years old. â€œA lot of people were killed on the same day in my area, houses were destroyed and several families were forced to move away. â€œMy schooling was affected â€“ I felt ashamed when the others talked about their fathers and I didnâ€™t have one. It all affected my studies.â€ She explains how hard the period was for her family, in particular her mother. â€œShe used to drink alcohol as she said it was the only way to forget the â€˜bad souvenirsâ€™ (memories) from that day.â€ Cezi is one of 11 family members at home.The Ampa Awagna project since its introduction in 2017 has trained 354 students in agricultural techniques and empowered 90 participants with the knowledge and skill to start their own companies. Projects like these are monumental in a region where 72 per cent of young people live on less than Â£1.50 per day. Famatou, 32, lives in the village of Saleykegna. She has struggled in the past to provide enough food for her family to eat. She explained how she had heard the Ampa Awagna project was providing small scale farmers with improved techniques growing crops to increase yields. Since her training, her onions have doubled in size and she has the ability to earn well and provide for her five children. â€œI get one production and I can earn 35,000 CFA (Â£54). Iâ€™m very happy now that my vegetable garden is doing better. I hope it will continue to be successful, otherwise, this will affect my family, I just love to see my garden grow.â€Aida, 36, lives in Takou village, near Sedhiou. She has five children and is 8 months pregnant but still works tirelessly on her small holding and with her chickens. The family only eat twice a day but Aida has a business plan to grow her poultry farm. â€œMy mother used to grow rice and peanuts just for food. People still do grow these here but only in the rainy season, which is very short. Lydie, 25, lives in Boukitingho near Ziguinchor. She attended the Ampa Awagna Y CareYMCA course and learned how to upscale the vegetables she grows by turning produce from the market into syrup, juice and marmalade. This enables her to earn a more consistent income the whole year-round. She is already teaching other women in the village the new skills she learned at the course. â€œWe have a joint piece of land in the village where we can grow our crops, and there we grow carrots, salad, onions and maize.Y Care International, the YMCAâ€™s aid and development charity, is empowering young women across the world and is supporting a programme in Senegal to address youth unemployment and help the next generation of farmers adapt to climate change. Beneficiaries like Fatou are able to create sustainable lives for themselves and their families.Bouya, 23, lives in a village on the outskirts of Kolda. An orphan, she lost both her parents to illness. Until now Bouya has been totally dependent on her uncle for support. â€œIâ€™ve just completed the agricultural training camp at Ampa Awagna and I am now planning to develop my own smallholding. The plot of land belonged to my father.  My idea is to start growing okra, lettuce, tomato and cucumber â€“ okra is a great crop because it is resistant to the heat.Laurentine, 26, runs a smallholding of pigs near Kolda. She is using the new farming methods she learnt on the Ampa Awangna camp and is extremely positive about the future. â€œBefore the training, we used traditional methods. The programme taught me the modern way is to keep them in the shelter as when they wander around they can bring back diseasesâ€. She now has 40 pigs and hopes in the next 10 years to move to a much larger holding where she wants 200-300 pigs.Belange, 23, lives in the village of Soutoure, near Kolda. Having excelled at the initial 2-week agricultural training camp at Ampa Awagna, Belange was asked to complete the 50-day intensive agricultural camp. She explained: â€œWhen I returned, I started growing in my vegetable garden, rearing pigs and poultry. I am earning much more than I did before the training. Iâ€™m growing tomatoes, peppers and chillis and I have much more output. Our life is better now â€“ we donâ€™t need to get help from others or have to ask people for money.â€Khady, 32, watering her crops of Aubergine and Ochre near Ziguinchor. Watering the crops to ensure they produce the best yields takes several hours a day.A beneficiary of the Y CareYMCA Ampa Awagna, Belange, 23 stands marking the spot, where the rice harvest should have reached. For this century things are changing for the better for women. I think in the future there will be a role reversal. Where previously, women were required to stay at home, they are now far more skilled and empowered.
