Alphonse George Manga, regional executive secretary for YMCA Senegal, explained: â€œWe are in a changing world, we canâ€™t stay in the past. For this century things are changing for the better for women. I think in the future there will be a role reversal. Where previously, women were required to stay at home, they are now far more skilled and empowered. They can do and be whatever they want if they are just given a chance and a little bit of help.â€According to estimates from UN agencies, the conflict in Casamance, Senegal, claimed the lives of over 5,000 people. The Movement of Democratic Forces in Casamance (MFDC) emerged in 1982 as an armed separatist group advocating for independence, creating a guerilla force who began attacks on the Senegalese army in 1990.In lower Casamance, 78 villages were completely destroyed, creating&nbspover 60,000 internally displaced people (IDPs) and subjected them to a life of fewer opportunities. Tens of thousands also crossed borders seeking refuge in Guinea-Bissau and the Gambia.Although an eventual ceasefire was implemented in 2014, today few MFDC combatants remain and violent incidents are in decline. The fear of sporadic attacks has now been replaced by far greater fears of youth unemployment and food insecurities driven by the changing climate.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesHigh levels of poverty and hunger persist in Senegal despite solid economic growth in recent years. Chronic malnutrition affects&nbspapproximately 17 per cent of children younger than 5 years of age, according to the UN World Food Program.Countries in the Sahel who rely on agriculture as primary sources of food and income are most at risk of crises and disasters. Unpredictable weather patterns, frequent droughts, floods and land desalinisation threaten the livelihoods of vulnerable communities.In Dakar, street artists from all over the world make their markThe Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change has stated: â€œA number of countries in Africa who already face semi-arid conditions may see a reduction in projected crop yield by up to 50 per cent&nbspin 2020 and reduced revenues by as much as 90 per cent by 2100.â€However, a new generation of small scale farming has emerged from women in the region. They are defying&nbspwhat predominantly male farming practices&nbsphave done for generations and are adapting to the climate changes.Most Senegalese&nbsphave noticed changes in the weather and seasons â€“ they talk of drought, increases in temperature and distinctly shorter rainy seasons but most do not draw the connection with global climate change.Y Care International, the YMCAâ€™s aid and development charity, is empowering young women across the world and is supporting a programme in Senegal to address youth unemployment and help the next generation of farmers adapt to the climate crisis.Leigh Daynes, CEO for Y Care International, explains:&nbspâ€œThe high unemployment and poverty levels experienced by young people in this remote and rural area of Casamance have only been further exacerbated by climate change. Families are now really struggling to cope with the shortfall of crops and having enough food to eat.Only the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailâ€œWorking in partnership with YMCA Senegal, the Ampa Awagna project has been carefully designed to equip young people with the knowledge and skills to adapt to the changing climate, maximise their yields and ersify and market new products.The woman changing the conversation around climate changeDavid Attenborough warns â€˜moment of crisisâ€™ on climate change has comeEU to dedicate a quarter of its budget fighting climate changeâ€œIt is becoming evident that it is the young women who are leading the way:&nbspthey are desperate to gain new expertise, they are bold and resilient and are demonstrating real entrepreneurial flair. We believe that mobilising and empowering young women to set up their own businesses is the way forward for the development of rural Senegal.â€Since the introduction of the project in 2017, 354 young people have been educated in environmentally sustainable agricultural techniques, with the aim of reaching a total of 800 enrolments by the end of 2022. The ripple effect from supporting so many young people and their families in a rapidly changing climate.Projects like these are monumental in a region where 72 per cent of young people live on less than Â£1.50 per day. The varied landscapes and lives of residents wedged in these borderlands speak of two different systems that have coexisted on one anotherâ€™s doorstep.Far from the marches and salvos of tear gas and petrol bombs over the past half-year of anti-government protests that have convulsed Hong Kong, the residents in this border realm have borne witness to both rapid urbanisation, as China booms, and the preservation of a slower pace of life.About 20 miles&nbsplong, this boundary meanders between fish ponds, farmland, sleepy traditional villages and grassy hills on the Hong Kong side, with the gleaming skyscrapers of Chinaâ€™s high-tech city of Shenzhen on the other. Everything is good, even the streets are beautiful.â€Over past decades of political upheaval in communist China, waves of mainlanders flooded across the border into Hong Kong, seeking peace and a better life. Lam still remembers the flashlights of the British-run police piercing the dark as they chased illegal immigrants making a dash for freedom.Andrew Kwok, an old fish farmer living in the area, recalls those who drowned making the perilous crossing. â€œThere were a lot of them, hundreds of dead bodies in the river,â€ he says.The flickering, lonely torches have now been replaced by a vibrant mega-city with a million flashing lights. The living quality for people on both sides may have converged, but a gulf remains. For these two peoples, it remains a struggle to reconcile shifting eras, values and dreams.Merrin Ke, 23, grew up in Shenzhen but got her masters degree from Hong Kongâ€™s Polytechnic University. Premium.Activists say incident fits in wider agenda of ruling party 'of persecuting Muslims'It has become commonplace in Narendra Modiâ€™s India for senior political figures to speak of Muslim immigrant workers in extremely derogatory terms - usually as â€œinfiltratorsâ€, sometimes as â€œtermitesâ€.And that rhetoric bore fruit this week in the major city of Bengaluru, formerly Bangalore, where the shanty homes of hundreds of labourers were bulldozed on the pretext that they were housing â€œsuspected illegal immigrantsâ€.The action, taken with police involvement yet seemingly on no official orders, has left hundreds homeless - either forced to share the limited space in those huts that are still standing, or else sleep on the streets.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesAnd while the city authority is framing the incident as the actions of a rogue middle-ranking official, it has been welcomed by the local branch of Mr Modiâ€™s ruling BJP party, which called it â€œthe right decisionâ€.The incident began last Sunday when men in JCB bulldozers, flanked by plainclothes policemen, descended on the 600-home informal settlement of Kariyammana Agrahara, to the east of the city.Indiaâ€™s female politicians bombarded with vitriolic online abuseMan killed by chicken at illegal cockfight in IndiaBezos trip turns into PR nightmare as Amazon promises â€˜1m Indian jobsâ€™India's top court rules ban on internet in Kashmir 'unconstitutional'Toiling in Indiaâ€™s sewersThey declared that all those present were illegal Bangladeshi migrants, and started tearing apart their homes.Videos that have since gone viral on social media show the residents trying to produce their voter ID cards, biometric registration documents known as Aadhaar, and other evidence that they were in fact born and raised in other states of India.But the police continued regardless, later telling a local newspaper that they have neither the time nor the money to verify such documents with other state authorities.The destruction ended after around 200 homes were destroyed, and after submissions by legal activists the Karnataka state High Court issued a stay order on Wednesday, as well as an immediate inquiry into both the police and municipal corporation to determine how something like this could happen.Lekha Adavi, a member of the Alternative Law Forum collective which has been providing Bengaluruâ€™s migrant workers with free legal support, told The Independent that those living in the slum came to the city from other Indian states like West Bengal, Assam, or even within Karnataka itself.Only the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailAnd even if they were illegal immigrants from Bangladesh, or third, fourth generation migrants, neither the municipal authorities nor the local police has the jurisdiction to act in the way it did - that would be a matter for the federal authorities.Ms Adavi said the incident was particularly concerning because it came just days after the local BJP legislative assembly member (MLA) for the area, Aravind Limbavali, tweeted a video of the settlement, saying it was â€œwithout cleanlinessâ€¦ a site of illegal activityâ€ and housing people who â€œare suspect to be illegal immigrants of Bangladeshâ€.Such comments do not exist in isolation. title: young morticians devastating inside job
story: Its just one of the many devastating moments he has had to face in his busy job as a mortician, but Noah, , is not alone.More and more younger people are ditching traditional jobs to become funeral directors, embalmers and morticians in an attempt to shake up and modernise the death industry in America.These millennials aim to offer a less sombre service - and help families feel closer to their loved ones - but the job doesnt come without its dficulties.From seeing close friends come through the mortuary to be embalmed, to piecing suicide victims faces back together so their family can see them one last time, these young morticians are forced to leave their emotions at the door on a daily basis.Jordan Tyjeski, , juggles her job as a licenced funeral director in Wisconsin, US, with her hobby as a two-time world champion weight lter.She says: â€œI was a senior in high school when I realised I wanted to work [in the funeral industry].I thought I could dress up and work with flowers, and I always thought embalming was interesting too. I didnâ€™t really understand what the job was then.While the rules are dferent in every US state, typically in Wisconsin funeral directors have to pass an associates degree followed by an apprenticeship and internship to become licenced.For Jordan, the apprenticeship involved a lot of time at the back of the mortuary, learning the art of embalming.But while shes grown used to the tough job, some cases have proved particularly hard to remain detached from.She says: â€œIf theyve shot themselves in the head, weve had to deal with that. One week here we had two -year-old suicides in one week. That was a terrible week.â€œSeeing those young boys and then seeing one of their families. It was devastating. Itâ€™s harder when you identy with people. Theyâ€™re the same age as my cousin.â€œAnd especially when people are my age, you think, â€˜Thatâ€™s my age, theyâ€™re , thatâ€™s meâ€™. Orthey look like your grandparents or theyâ€™re your parentsâ€™ age. Little things like that will get you.â€However, she insists: I absolutely love my job. I love meeting with families and being there for them. I love being the first person to reassure them.Meanwhile, theres long been myths and rumours on whether a body can move or make a noise after death.According to Jordan, it is in fact true- and shes seen it first hand.She says: â€œWhile Iâ€™ve never had a body move, sometimes their hand may fallits been held up when they died. It can make you jump, especially when it hits you.â€œThe scariest thing is when youâ€™re first transferring the body to the cot. Itâ€™s called the death rattle. When you pick them up their lungs squeeze a bit of air, it makes a gurgling sound. Itâ€™s hard.â€œI do everything in my power not to yell or put my hands up.And while this job might not be for everyone, I love being the first person to reassure families that everythingâ€™s going to be okay.Noah Watry, , is a licenced funeral director from Milwaukee, Wisconsin.Â Noah pledged to bring his creativity to the job when he first started training, and hes stayed true to his word.From hunting down bands for funeral ceremonies, to organising a taco truck for one family to honour their loved ones passion for food, he tries to ensure they all have a very modern and memorable goodbye.A typical day for Noah can begin in the early hours of the morning,hes the on-call director, with some nights seeing him collecting up to six bodies single-handedly.Sadly, some deaths have impacted Noah more than others.He says: â€œThere are a few Iâ€™ll never forget. My first child Iâ€™ll never forget because she looked exactly like my niece.â€œI remember she was the same age and looked exactly like her. I remember calling my sister straight after. It was a car accident, she was eight years old.While many deaths can be peaceful, others require a great deal of skill to ensure the deceaseds family can see them looking like themselves before they say goodbye.Noah says: â€œIâ€™ve had bad suicides, where theyâ€™ve shot themselves and Iâ€™ve had to put their face back together. Itâ€™s almost like plastic surgery sometimes.â€œThere would be a lot of suturing back up. There will be re-forming of the face. We ask the families for photos of them, taken from dferent anglesthey have them, to recreate their face.â€œThereâ€™s dferent materials we use. Sometimes you have to use clay, sometimes you have to use putties. Then youâ€™re able to use cosmetics and cover that up, to form the face exactly how it needs to be. It definitely takes some time.While Noah has been in the industry for several years now, he still struggles with old stereotypes of funeral directors - and its even previously impacted his love le.He says: â€œSometimes people look at you like youâ€™re an old creepy person!I once went on a date with a girl and when she found out what I did, she was like, â€˜Oh my gosh, how do you expect to find someone to marry then â€™ I was like, â€˜Wow I guess thatâ€™s not going to be you then!â€™â€Mum Evie Vargas, , from Chicago works for Frigid Fluid, a company that creates embalming fluids. She recently left her job as a funeral director.She says of her time as a director: â€œYouâ€™re ultimately doing a really great thing for a family because youâ€™re preparing their loved one for that final goodbye.In some cases emotions can run high and Evie admits shes been at the receiving end of some very angry outbursts from family members before.She says: â€œItâ€™s something you have to deal with. You have to understand theyâ€™re not mad at you, theyâ€™re mad at the situation. You have to brush it off.â€œWhen I first started I would take it personally. It took me a while to realise theyâ€™re not mad at me and I did the best that I could.â€As a younger person in the industry, Evie is now keen to embrace new trends.She says: â€œI think people are more in charge of their deaths than ever. People have dferent ideas, like green burials. People donâ€™t want to be embalmed and want toback to the Earth naturally.â€Brian Waters, , is married with two kids. He works for two small family funeral homes in Indiana, having grown up with his parents in the industry.While Brian admits he found his parents jobs odd and often scary when he was a child, it soon became normal and began to interest him more in his teenage years.However, being from a small area also means hes seen people he knows pass away too.He says: More often than not [its people I know]. It is a lot harder when thereâ€™s a personal connection.For Brian, some of the worst memories he has are following a sudden or unexpected death.He says: â€œSudden tragic loss is awful, when you hear those guttural screams of grief. Those sounds never leave your head. Theyâ€™re always bouncing around in there. Itâ€™s hair raising, it gives you goosepimples.â€œThat often happensitâ€™s a child of any age.â€Tragically, Brians job was made much harder in  when he and his we sadly lost a baby of their own.He now admits the tragedy gave him a new perspective on the job.Brian runs his own podcast on the funeral industry, in an effort to lt the stigma around how much ceremonies cost to organise. He insists, unlike many may believe, most funeral homes are barely getting by.He says: â€œI think people think because we dress up, we wear a suit and the cars are clean, that thereâ€™s money falling out our ears. Itâ€™s a really tight ship for most funeral homes these days.â€œWe can work anything from  to  hours a week. Thereâ€™s many sleepless nights, your brain starts to slow down, but thatâ€™s small town family business.â€Ingrid Johansen, , works part-time at a local funeral home cemetery in El Cerrito, Calornia.Ingrid currently goes to college in Sacramento, while working part-time - mainly helping out in the embalming room as well as front of house.For Ingrid however, the hardest part of the job is seeing people her own age come through the doors - especially following a violent or gruesome death.Ingrid now hopes to push for new traditions and transparency in what she does, and one way is through death cafes.These are set up across the world for people to go and chat to others openly about death, should they be worried about opening up to their family.She says: With DeathÂ Cafes, Iâ€™d love to see the eventual expansion into schools , and for more expansion into cities small towns as well.While their jobs prove emotionally draining at times however, all these brave morticians agree that, above all , theyre happy and proud to be helping families at their most dficult time.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: prince charles harry meghan duchy of cornwall money norman baker
story: Butyou think that means there will be no more of your money spent on them, well, think again. Prince Charles will see to that.Harry will continue to receive Â£million from his father, but although Charles has amassed a personal fortune of over Â£million, the money might not be coming from that closely guarded pot.The prince could instead be paying him through a outdated racket called the Duchy of Cornwall.Charles could claim this as a business expense which means he can reduce the amount of tax he pays. The public would be paying for Harry by the back door.Harry of course has no connection with this sprawling property company called the Duchy, but that has never stopped Charles benefiting from its special tax status.The status of the Duchy has been contested for decades and while Charles insists it is private, thats strongly disputed by others.Charles has also claimed as business expenses the cost of  personal staff to pamper him â€“ butlers, valets, gardeners.He had the cheek to argue that Camillaâ€™s personal costs even before they married were a Duchy expense so claimed for her staff, her travel, her jewellery, and the stabling of her horses.And he got away with it. The line was only drawn when he tried to claim his polo ponies as business expenses.In my time in Parliament I saw plenty of MPs claiming for duck houses, moat cleaning and the like. Is this dferent So what is this Duchy  Well itâ€™s not just in Cornwall where it has land. Its tentacles stretch far and wide. It even owns the Oval cricket ground. Extra cover for the Prince as he hits the taxpayer for six.The Duchy turns in a profit of over Â£million a year. That is money that many argue should go straight to the Treasury. Instead it becomes pocket money for the Prince.He has reluctantly agreed he should pay tax on this money but the vast array of creative expenses he conjures up means in a recent year when the Duchy made Â£.million, only Â£.million was paid in tax at  per cent.That can only be explainedhe dreamed up more than Â£million in expenses.Charles says the Duchy is a â€œprivate estateâ€ â€” which it is legally, but it acts like a public body that reverts to the Crown when theres no Duke of Cornwall.It has had notices served on it by the Health and Safety Executive and the Environment Agency and they can only be served on a public body.It is the harbour authority for the Isles of Scilly. The Information Commissioner has ruled it is public.But by insisting it is private means the Duchyâ€™s accounting practices can be hidden away. No right of access for the National Audit Office. No freedom of information.If you go cap in hand and bow and scrape, they might let you see some old Duchy paperwork. On the other hand, they might not.In this medieval throwback, Charles scoops up the property of anybody who dies without leaving a will. The general right for a King or Queen to do this was abolished in . But not in the Duchy.Yet this so-called private estate suddenly becomes public when it suits Charles. Unlike any other private estate in Britain, it doesnâ€™t pay any corporation tax or capital gains tax.No wonder Charles is worth over Â£million.Suddenly the private Prince becomes a public figure, demanding â€“ and getting â€“ the right to change government legislation that affects the Duchy in a way he doesnâ€™t like.To be fair, he does pay the market rent for the vast property he occupies at Highgrove. He pays it to the Duchy which then s the money to him, tax-free, as the Duke of Cornwall in a sort of merry money-go-round.He got Duchy employees to grow trees on Duchy land and then sold the timber to... The Duchy. Charles pocketed Â£.million tax free for this racket.The Duchy of Cornwall is not some hobby growing a bit of organic lettuce here and there. Nor is it a small collection of twee cottages as you might infer from the pictures the Duchy uses in its publications.No, it is a hard-headed ruthless property company with advantages in tax and law that no other company has.It is a massive money-making machine for Prince Charles, money that rightly belongs to us all but that he erts to himself.Itâ€™s time for this medieval monstrosity to be sorted out. As Margaret Thatcher once famously said: â€œWe want our money back.â€Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bbc boss accepts change london elite
story: THE bloated BBC is finally sipping expensive champagne in a last-chance saloon surrounded by Â­Corbynista socialists.Boris Johnson stands within touching distance of enacting Tory revenge on the Blatantly Biased Corporation, which his genius sidekick Dominic Cummings has been quietly plotting for  years.But an early departure this week by Director-General Tony Hall gives the Beeb one final chance to hire a boss who accepts it must change.A boss who believes its news coverage must represent more than the London remoaning media elite.A boss who knows it is only fair for the BBC to fund the licence fee for those over .A boss who accepts itâ€™s wrong to send people to jail for failing to pay the BBCâ€™s poll tax.It was under those circumstances I apprehensively switched on Newsnight on Monday night to watch nearly the entire show dedicated to navel-gazing about the corporationâ€™s future.Here was the chance to finally prove its news arm could provide fair and critical coverage of the BBCâ€™s very obvious Â­weaknesses.So how did they do  Even worse than I expected.In truly bewildering circumstances, BBC presenter Emily Maitlis interviewed four long-time BBC defenders â€” ista political editor Nicholas Watt, its greatest presenter David Dimbleby, former chairman Michael Grade and unfunny comedian Katy Brand â€” about how untouchable the BBC is.That propaganda droned on for  Â­minutes.When the BBCâ€™s critics finally got a chance, near the end of the show, they got exactly half the time to make their case â€” just eight minutes and  seconds.Astonishingly, the producers had managed to book three so-called critics who actually seemed to quite like the Â­organisation, none of whom called for the abolition of the licence fee.Itâ€™s this sort of tone-deaf programming that makes it obvious why BBC News Â­completely missed the surge towards Brexit in  and the historic Northern â€œblue waveâ€ that voted Conservative for the first time last month.The Government is right to ban Â­ministers from appearing on Radio â€™s increasingly irrelevant and out-of-touch Today programme.Of course, our top politicians should be held to account. Which they are on Â­commercial rivals like Nick Ferrari on LBC or Julia Hartley-Brewer on TalkRADIO.At least those stations donâ€™t start from a position of: â€œBrexit is evil and a majority Tory government isnâ€™t much Â­better.â€No one is proposing for a single second the BBC be axed. But the poll tax that funds it should be.Its websites that write clickbait about TV shows like Love Island â€” well Â­covered by other online outlets â€” should be stopped too. Not to mention its recent push into the already saturated podcast market.The BBCâ€™s job is not to be a monolith, shutting out commercial organisations and dominating the entertainment and news industries.Thatâ€™s what makes yesterdayâ€™s decision to axe Victoria Derbyshireâ€™s BBC programme ridiculous.Her award-winning morning show is one of the only news programmes on the Â­corporation to properly cover the working class.It is unbiased, feisty, fair and will cover entertainment stories or whatever happens to be the splash of The Sun that day, without the snobbery of the rest of BBC News.That sort of non-commercial show is just the type the Beeb should be making. But â€” of course â€” under its latest cuts, it is the first to go.The next Director-General must be an outsider who understands the madness of the BBCâ€™s current priorities and is Â­prepared to enact real change.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: prince charles save monarchy passion projects
story: Just  hours after Trumpand Thunbergmade blatantly political statements at the World Economic Forum, our future king was doing the same thing.Whenever will he learn His family is currently in the midst of its biggest crisis since Princess Dianaâ€™s death.The Queen is , with a very ill husband.The time has come for this man to step up and save the monarchy, not continue with his overtly political passion projects.The environment and talking to plants have been hobbies for Charles for many years.He is desperate to take ownership of the fact he was on this bandwagon before Greta Thunberg was a twinkle in the eye of her fame-hungry mother.But thatâ€™s not the bloody point.Heâ€™s not running for office. story: This figureâ€™s concern is that Boris Johnsonâ€™s Government is, rightly, keen on infrastructure â€” seeing new roads and railways and better broadband as key to raising the countryâ€™s growth rate â€” but these projects tend to come in late and over budget in Britain.The danger for the Tories is that, at the next election in , they may have little more than plans to show for their efforts.Downing Street is acutely aware of this risk.It is already thinking about how it can make sure that people can see and feel visible improvements in their daily lives before the next election.They know that getting those who voted Tory for the first time to stick with them will not be easy.â€œIf these people sense that we are not delivering for them, theyâ€™ll desert us in droves,â€ warns one key Boris ally.In an attempt to ensure that the Government does fulfil its pledges, No is trying to create greater accountability in Whitehall.I understand it is planning to implement a â€œdashboard processâ€ for domestic policy.This means a named minister and official will be in charge of ensuring the delivery of a policy, with No able to constantly check whether it is on track or not.One policy very much not on track is HS. title: foundling children monthly lottery
story: The rules of the monthly draw at the Foundling Hospital in London were that a white ball secured a place at the institution for a baby of less than two months old.A red ball put them on the institution.A poignant image from the hospitalâ€™s earliest years, following its opening in  is what inspired my second novel, The Foundling.Much like the hospitalâ€™s founder Thomas Coram, I was shocked toWith no social services or formalised model of adoption, children were left to the care of the parish, farmed out to relatives or simply abandoned.And high infant mortality rates meant that  per cent of children in the capital died before their fth birthday.Coram, a sailor and businessman, was so disturbed by the sight of dead or dying babies at the roadside that he petitioned Parliament for a royal charter to establish a home for the cityâ€™s unwanted children.His revolutionary Foundling Hospital was built with space for  children â€” and was massively oversubscribed.Poverty, a lack of contraception and the shame of illegitimacy led women to flock from all over the land to hand their infants into its care â€” knowing they would probably never see them again.Some left tokens with their sons or daughters as a means of identication, in case they found themselves able to reclaim their children years later.The most common were scraps of fabric torn from the childâ€™s or motherâ€™s clothes, as well as coins, hairpins and buttons.The token was recorded and the child given a number, which they wore on a tag around their neck.All Foundling children were given new names to prevent them finding their parents later in le, and to protect the motherâ€™s identity.Tom Mackenzie, now , was one of the last to be taken into the hospital â€” and describes le in the Forties as â€œDickensianâ€.He was born in , exactly  years after the hospital was founded, to a Scottish Presbyterian mother and Irish Catholic father, who were forbidden by their families to marry.Tomâ€™s father Raymond then emigrated to South Africa, and soon after he left, his mother Jean found out she was pregnant.She felt she had no option but to put her baby son into care and Tom â€” born Derek Craig â€” was given a place at the hospital, which by that time housed  children, having moved from Bloomsbury in the West End to Berkhamsted, Herts.Tom recalls being â€œterrorisedâ€ by the older boys, who would electrocute the younger children, force them to fight and even dangle them out of windows.He told The Sun: â€œThey tied one of the boys to a chair and lowered him out of the upstairs window. Then they heard a house master coming down the corridor and everyone rushed to get back into bed.They dropped the boy tied to the chair and he crashed to the ground below and broke his back. We never saw him again.â€Nights were â€œabsolutely fearsomeâ€, when the lights went out and the dormitory monitor was in charge.Tom, who now lives in Plymouth and has written his le story, The Last Foundling, said: â€œWe knew that before he went to sleep heâ€™d want to have his bit of fun.â€One day, while waiting outside the headmasterâ€™s office aged , he overheard a staff member say his motherâ€™s name and where she lived.He secretly kept the information to himself during his ten years in the institution and five years spent with a foster family and their daughters, Monica and Janet. After another five years in the Army, Tom finally tracked down his mother, who by that time was married to a solicitor and worked as a legal secretary in Edinburgh.He said: â€œI wanted to make it a surprise. I went into the lobby and the receptionist rang up to Jean.â€œI couldnâ€™t face her as she came down the stairs, so I had my back to her and heard footsteps. My heart was racing and I thought, â€˜What am I going to say â€™â€œShe came up behind me and I turned around, and she said, â€˜Can I help you â€™ I said, â€˜I donâ€™t knowâ€™, and she said, â€˜Do I know you â€™I said, â€˜Perhaps in another worldâ€™.â€ After an emotional reunion the pair exchanged letters. Then Jean invited Tom to live with her and her husband, Duncan Mackenzie.And in another twist of fate, decades later, after Duncan died, Jean resumed her relationship with Tomâ€™s real father, Raymond.More than  years after they were wrenched apart, Tomâ€™s family was finally reunited.But most of the , children cared for by the Foundling Hospital were not so lucky, with just one per cent being claimed by their families.Of the rest, boys were prepared for careers in the Army or Navy, and girls trained for domestic service, all of them turned out to fend for themselves in their early teens.Education was not a priority, as former foundling John Caldicott remembers. Now , he lived at the hospital from  to .He said: â€œWe were brought up aswe were in the Georgian era, wearing unorms and marching everywhere.â€œWe were children of our time. The discipline would not be accepted today. Boys were separated from girls and it was a monastic style of le.â€After leaving the hospital at , John was apprenticed to a radio and music shop in Oxford and went on to work for Oxfordshire County Council.When the hospital opened in the Georgian era, apprenticeships were an informal model of adoption, with an employer taking over a childâ€™s care and putting them to work in exchange for food and lodgings.The Foundling Hospital model was deemed so successful that similar institutions were set up in New York, Paris and around the world.In Britain, that all changed with the  Children Act, which recommended that children should be taken back by their birth mothers or found homes with foster parents.After the hospitalâ€™s closure in  it became Ashlyns School, which still contains stained-glass windows, a staircase and monuments from the original London hospital.The Coram childrenâ€™s charity continues the Foundling Hospitalâ€™s work to this day, as one of Britainâ€™s largest independent adoption agencies.And as for the thousands of children who passed through the hospitalâ€™s doors, their history will be digitised in a new project that will make pre- records available for the first time.Thanks to a Â£.million National Lottery Heritage Fund grant, history buffs will be able to view petition letters from mothers seeking hospital places for their children, as well as the heartbreaking tokens they left with them.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: what is national minimum wage uk
story: But what is it now and what will it increase to The National Minimum Wage is currently the amount workers under , but of school-leaving age, are entitled to.The first National Minimum Wage was set in  by the Labour government.Before that, no official rate existed although trade unions battled hard to fight their workers corner.The National Minimum Wage was re-branded to the National Living Wage in  for those over .In April , the National Living Wage was increased by  pence-an-hour to Â£..And in December , Sajid Javid announced a Living Wage increase of p to Â£., giving a boost to all those over .But the great news is that there are increases across the board for all age groups and those on apprenticeship schemes.Heres the latest national limits as of April  that are legally binding:With the increase on April , , these will now stand at:Anyone who thinks they are not getting the National Living Wage or National Minimum Wage should complain to their employer in the first instance.If this does not get anywhere, the next step is to take the complaint to HMRC who will investigate.Chancellor Sajid Javid has announced there will be an increase in the National Minimum Wage from Â£. to Â£. an hour in April.The .% rise is double the rate of average annual wage growth and also twice the current rate of inflation, as well as the legal minimumâ€™s biggest cash rise ever since it came into force in .The increase in minimum wage will deliver an extra Â£ a year into the pockets of almost three million who earn it.Those who are self-employed, voluntary workers, company directors and family members who live in the home of the employer and do household chores do not qualy for either rate.There is no dference in pay for those that live in London compared to where.The only discrepancy is for people working in agriculture or horticulture.Workers already employed before October , , are entitled to the pay set under their contract of employment.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA cobbler has had his big toe amputated then sewn onto his hand after losing his thumb in a freak accident. David Lee had been trimming the heel of a shoe in his shop when his hand suddenly got caught in the machine and he was forced to watch his severed thumb drop onto the floor. After freeing himself, he immediately started thinking about how he would be able to earn a living after the accident.He told Derbyshire Live: â€œStraight away, I knew how bad it was and I just worried that I wouldnâ€™t be able to fix shoes again. I cried my eyes out when I thought about it, as I thought I was going to lose my shop.â€œI was more concerned about that than my thumb because this is my passion. It all happened so fast but I felt no pain at all and straight away just turned all the machines off and actually went outside for a fag, while I waited for the ambulance!â€ David went to Kingâ€™s Mill Hospital, in Mansfield, where he was then transferred to the Pulvertaft Hand Centre, at Royal Derby Hospital where the idea was put to him that a new â€œthumbâ€ could be created using one of his big toes. Hearing that there could be a chance for him to carry on his job, David instantly said he would do it. He said: â€œAs soon as it was put to me that attaching my toe gave me a chance to carry on my job, I instantly said letâ€™s do it. Iâ€™d never heard of a procedure like this before but I also knew that the Royal Derby Hospital had the best hand surgical team in the country.â€ Five days later, David underwent the -hour operation surgeons spent around  hours, which has been performed only a handful of times at the University Hospitals of Derby and Burton and is only considered for patients with certain types of amputations. Miss Jill Arrowsmith, one of the two consultant hand surgeons who performed the operation, said: â€œThis procedure is only offered to patients who have lost a lot of their thumb, usually down to close to the knuckle. â€œNot having any of the thumb can be very disabling, especially for those who do a manual job. This type of injury could mean that these patients are not able to remain at work, so weâ€™re delighted to be able to provide this treatment option. â€œToe-to-thumb reconstructions are quite rare but we have been really pleased with all of the outcomes these patients have achieved. There are lots of dferent ways to reconstruct thumbs but using the big toe gives the best al and cosmetic benefits, as it is the thing most like a thumb on the body.

Some months all Amy could stomach was a teaspoon of water every five minutes, given to her night and day by Angela and Ross just to keep the little girl hydrated enough. When her daughter took a particularly bad turn on August  - just two weeks after her fth birthday - Angela took Amy to Royal Aberdeen Childrenaposs Hospital. Angela claims hospital nurses carried out tests, raising concerns about Amyaposs problems balancing and that one of her eyes appeared to be larger than the other. The mum-of-two says Amy was scheduled to have an MRI at the hospital the next day at pm but this didnapost happen until after pm when Amy stopped breathing. Amy was then taken for emergency surgery to put a shunt in her brain to relieve some of the pressure before she could be flown to Edinburghaposs Royal Hospital for Sick Children on August . In Edinburgh, surgeons were able to remove the entire tumour from Amyaposs brain and the mass was found to be a cancerous medulloblastoma growth. The oncologist allegedly told Angela that with radiotherapy and chemotherapy, Amy would have an % chance of beating the cancer completely and surviving. With newfound hope, the little girlaposs family waited for weeks for her to wake up for treatment but Amy never opened her eyes again.  Angela said: Amy was a happy little girl, everybody loved her. She was amazing. She was a natural performer and loved to sing and dance. She was obsessed with Cats the musical. She was just so full of le and then bang - she wasnapost anymore. The surgeons in Edinburgh couldnapost have done any more. When they managed to remove the whole tumour, it gave us a sense of hope. Thataposs what doctors do, they fix people. It was a huge shock to find out Amy had cancer. I knew something was really wrong for months but I never expected that. It was just unreal. It was like it wasnapost happening to me. It was like I was standing back watching somebody aposs le. But the oncologist was really hopeful. He told us Amy had an % chance of survival with treatment. She just needed to be awake for the treatment. As time went on and she wasnapost coming around, I realised there wasnapost going to be a happy ending. We know now that her brain stem was pretty much dead from the pressure of the tumour and the bleed. And the brain stem doesnapost regenerate. If she had just got to Edinburgh sooner,Aberdeen had done the MRI they scheduled,someone had listened to me when Amy was in pain, she would have survived. It all comes down to her diagnosis not being fast enough because thereaposs a complete lack of awareness of the symptoms of brain tumours in children. Itaposs not fair, she should still be here. She didnapost even get the chance to fight and she had a lot of fight to give. A medulloblastoma PNET is a malignanttumour formed from primitive or poorly developed brain cells, according to the NHS. Less than  children a year develop medulloblastoma in the UK. However, it is still the most common malignant brain tumour in children, representing % of all childhood brain tumours. They are most common in children between the ages of three and eight, and are slightly more common in boys than girls. Symptoms include: nausea and vomiting , lethargy and irritability, headaches, clumsiness, dficulty with tasks like handwriting, gradual decline in school work, changes in personality and behaviour and abnormal gait. After being informed that Amy would only live for three months without cancer treatment, her family made the heartbreaking decision to take her off le support. Amy was transferred to Rachel House Childrenaposs Hospice in Kinross where she took her last breath on September  while in her mumaposs arms. The family held a funeral on October  and Amy was buried in a white cat costume to honour her love for Cats the musical. Her tragic death has had a devastating impact on Amyaposs family with Angela still struggling to process what has happened. And Amyaposs big sister Melissa Lornie, eight, wants nothing more than to see her sibling again. Angela said: Taking Amy off le support was the hardest decision but we knew she was going to die anyway. I was lying on the bed and Amy was lying on me with her head on my chest when she took her last breath. It was really peaceful. There was no struggling. It sounded like a really contented sigh when youaposre sleepy. And then she didnapost breathe again. I think she was waiting for it to just be me and her. We hadnapost been alone for so long, there were always doctors and nurses and family but as soon as we were alone she took her last breath. To this moment, I donapost think I have fully processed whataposs happened. I know sheaposs gone because she died on me but at random points in the day it hits me again. Itaposs like I have been totally paralysed. Getting up in the mornings is hard but I have to for Melissa. When Amy died a part of me died too. Melissa is really not good, she misses her sister. None of us like being in our house anymore. Itaposs like being trapped. There are so many bad memories.

Andrea Horvathova was found unconscious at a property in Mutley, Plymouth, on the evening of Sunday March , . The hearing was told her boyfriend suggested she had taken a couple of lines of speed, a couple of lines of MDMA, and maybe ketamine, along with spiced rum. Police had also been called to the address after a group of people were reported to be under the influence of drink and controlled drugs, Plymouth Live reports. Andrea and another woman were both suffering the effects and raced to Derrord Hospital. The other woman survived, but Andrea died three days later on March , aged just . An inquest, presided over by senior coroner Ian Arrow noted how she had amphetamine, alcohol, Ecstasy, cocaine and a potent designer drug nicknamed Flakka in her system. Flakka - also known as Alpha PVP, or alpha-Pyrrolidinopentiophenone - is a stimulant that has had catastrophic effects on some communities in the United States. Plymouth Coroners Court heard a pathologistaposs toxicology report found Andreaaposs heart and liver had been damaged. The combination of drugs would have very likely resulted in a heart attack, the court heard. She had no physical injuries on her body. A statement from a close friend of Andreaaposs was read to the court.  She said she had known Andrea for two years and they regularly went to social events.She said Andrea, who was born in the Czech Republic, had revealed she had grown up in a care home and in June  had met a man called Alex whom she had a relationship with and had talked about going travelling with. A dramatic video shows chaotic scenes as crowds of people wearing face masks while waiting to be tested fill jam-packed corridors of a hospital in Wuhan, where the virus originated. People who appear to be medical staff are seen in full protective body suits pointing and shouting as they try and make their way through the queues. In one disturbing scene, a patient appears to be slumped ill on a chair while a woman standing with him wails and shakes in apparent distress. France confirmed earlier this evening its first three cases of the Wuhan coronavirus, with one patient being hospitalised in Paris and another in the southwestern city of Bordeaux. Health Minister Agnes Buzyn told a news conference these were the first two confirmed cases in Europe and that more cases were likely to occur in France. earlier reported how tests for coronavirus on  people in the UK came back negative but there are checks ongoing on other people, according to the Chief Medical Officer Professor Chris Whitty. Mr Whitty spoke following a meeting of the Governmentaposs Cobra emergency committee in Whitehall, chaired by Health Secretary Matt Hancock. All the people tested in the UK had visited Wuhan. title: i sent auschwitz wedding day
story: NewsI was sent to Auschwitz on my wedding day - the Nazis even took my ringIbolya Knill remains bright and resilient as she reflects on the devastating turn her le took - she has told her story as she always promised she wouldshe survivedShareCommentsByEmily RetterSenior Feature Writer:,  JAN NewsIby Knill refuses to be shackled by her history " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Teenager Ibolya Knill was wearing bright red high-heeled sandals when she was rounded up by Nazi troops in surprised raids on Jewish homes in Hungary.A week later, the -year-old was to marry, and in the pocket of her carefree summer dress nestled a pair of wedding rings she had just had engraved with the date of their big day: June , . Tragically, that date was to take on a very dferent signicance.For when the morning of June  finally arrived, Ibolya â€“ known as Iby â€“ still wearing her red heels and by now filthy summer dress, found herself crammed â€œlike cattleâ€ into a wagon heading to the notorious death camp Auschwitz in Nazi-occupied Poland.Where there should have been flutters of girlish excitement in her stomach, now there was just a heavy, gnawing sense of dread. There was no way of getting word to her fiancÃ©, Gaspar, and there was no reasoning with the guards. â€œI went to them and said, â€˜Today is supposed to be my wedding dayâ€™,â€ she recalls. â€œThey said it made no dference. I didnâ€™t talk of [Gaspar] again. There were a group of us in the wagon who decided to stick together. But we also decided to talk of nothing from the past, not our families or friends. It was our way of coping. I didnâ€™t tell them.â€ Monday marks the th anniversary of the liberation of Auschwitz by Soviet troops. Iby, now , remains bright and resilient as she reflects on the devastating turn her le took. Originally from Bratislava, in what was then Czechoslovakia, she was born to a Jewish mother. After the Nazis invaded, she was smuggled to Hungary, where she lived with non-Jewish family of her father, carrying  documents that stated she was not a Jew. But in March , the Nazis also invaded Hungary. Iby was at the house of a Jewish friend that was raided, and she did not have her fake papers on her. Even with them she would have been in a precarious position, as she had been arrested and interrogated over her involvement in the resistance. She was also frightened of being caught out as an illegal immigrant. She confided these worries in a man she had recently met, Gaspar. He proposed, in the hope Hungarian citizenship would keep her safe.  Iby recalls: â€œWe had only known each other for a matter of days, but I think he fell in love with me. â€œUnder the circumstances, that was enough. People didnâ€™t know what was going to happen to them, and le moved quickly. â€œHe gave me money to buy the wedding rings and to get them engraved.â€ She would never see Gaspar, or those rings, again. Before she got on the transport to Auschwitz they were stripped from her, along with her earrings. The conditions of her five-day transport were appalling, and by the time she arrived at Auschwitz, exhausted and terried, Iby had every reason to feel utterly crushed. But instead, anger surged. Pushed onto the railway  of the death camp, she linked arms with friends she made during the journey.  Scared and starving though she was, Iby â€“ in her defiant red heels â€“ burst into the Hungarian national anthem, leading the group in song as they walked towards the campâ€™s notorious Angel of Death, Dr Josef Mengele. This was the man responsible for deciding which of the frailest new arrivals to send straight to the gas chambers. Her act of courage protected her and her new friends. She says: â€œWe didnâ€™t think we had anything to lose, and had been told to look livelywe wanted to live. Mengele laughed â€“ he thought it was funny. I remember him â€“ a very smart chap, with two dogs and two women in unorm behind him. He just waved us on through the gate. I was so angry. And that anger stayed with me. It helped me survive.â€ After her brush with Mengele, she was pushed into a â€œhuge roomâ€. â€œThey stripped me of everything but my high heels â€“ prisoners kept their shoes â€“ they looked absolutely crazy.â€  She is able to laugh a little, despite the horror of the memory. â€œPrisoners in striped pyjamas came and cut the hair all over our bodies. â€œWe were pushed into showers and dressed in rags.â€ Iby was not tattooed with a registration number, because the tattooists ran out of ink. She has since found it out:  it remains ingrained in her mind. She was marched to Birkenau, the largest of the sub-camps within Auschwitz, where prisoners were crammed  to a hut. Chillingly, â€œThere was no trees, grass or birdsong,â€ she recalls. Iby, who now lives in Leeds, West Yorks, has never ed to Auschwitz â€“ and has no desire to ever go back. â€œIâ€™m told itâ€™s still the same, the atmosphere has stayed the same,â€ she says. They lived in just two rooms - one containing buckets for toilets and another to sleep in.  â€œThe only way was to lie like spoons, heads on hips,â€ she says. â€œYou had to fight your way outyou needed to get to the buckets in the night. But you wouldnâ€™t be able to get back in. Youâ€™d have to sleep standing by the wall.â€ The prisoners called the green-flecked soup they were served from buckets â€˜grass foodâ€™. â€œBut the thirst was worse than the hunger,â€ she recalls. The only way she and the others knew which day it was, she says, was because once a week they were taken to be showered. The showers were in the same location as the notorious gas chambers â€“ and Iby had no way of knowing to which they would be taken. Worst of all, she explains, was the smell that pervaded the camp. â€œThe whole place smelt of burning flesh,â€ she says adding that she cannot attend a barbecue to this day.  She had no idea what had happened to her family, until one day a prisoner emptying the buckets told her that her mother was in Auschwitz, and searching for her. They never saw each other in the amp, but were reunited after the war. Later, Iby found out her father had been in Auschwitz, too. â€œBut he was gassed â€“ the very last time the gas chambers were used.â€ Iby herself left the death camp after â€œ days and  nightsâ€ â€“ still wearing her red heels, with her rebellious spirit burning bright. Pretending to be a nurse, she volunteered for a slave labour transport to another camp, in the hope it would be better. As she waited to be loaded onto a wagon, a teenage girl approached. Iby recalls: â€œShe was a twin. She and her sister and watched their parents go to the gas chambers, and were being experimented on by Josef Mengele. They knew that after that they would die. â€œShe asked me,I survived, to tell the story of Auschwitz. I promised I would.â€

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Starbucks and McDonaldaposs have closed down branches in Shanghai as China desperately battles to fight against the growing number of coronavirus cases in the country. The city,  miles from virus epicentre Wuhan, has also shut down its cinemas in a bid to prevent the spread of the deadly illness, according to Bangkok Post.The disease has killed  people in China, with experts believing that number could continue to rise. Year of the Rat celebrations are also being cancelled around the country due to fears that gatherings of large crowds could help the virus spread at an alarming rate. The Lunar New Year is the countryaposs biggest holiday, and a time when many people would travel to visit family. Today, Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam declared a virus emergency in the Asian financial hub, announcing several measures to limit the cityaposs links with mainland China. Schools, already closed for the holiday, will now remain shut until February , while inbound and outbound flights and high speed rail trips between Hong Kong and Wuhan have been halted. Lam said confirmed that all official visits to the mainland and official Lunar New Year celebrations would be scrapped immediately.She also said she had sought the assistance from Chinaaposs State Council to ensure on-going mask supplies were adequate. They may also ask universities to extend holidays too. Lamaposs statements came hours after she ed from the World Economic Forum in Davos and amid broader tensions as her team grapples with at times violent anti-government protests that have rumbled on for seven months. I hereby urge all citizens stay united to fight against the epidemic to protect all Hong Kong peopleaposs health and safety, Lam said. She added that it would be impractical to shut down all border crossings with the mainland. Some protesters have railed against growing interference from Beijing seeking to curb the cityaposs freedoms while others have expressed fear over greater integration with the mainland. The cityaposs health authorities have confirmed  coronavirus cases, all linked to Wuhan, where the virus first appeared, with a further  people being treated as suspected of having the disease. The first case was confirmed on Wednesday, a -year-old man visiting from Wuhan who crossed by high-speed rail from neighbouring Shenzhen.The condition of one of the people confirmed with the virus deteriorated on Saturday and the patient was now on a respirator, Hong Kongaposs government funded broadcaster RTHK reported.Hong Kong earlier deployed temperature screening equipment at the airport and the high-speed rail station. Air passengers are required to fill in health declaration forms while isolation wards have been set-up in hospitals.Reuters witnesses have described the widespread use of masks in offices and on public transport, a reflection of the cityaposs strong memories of an earlier coronavirus crisis.

title: brexit countdown have dundonians been preparing ahead of exit from the eu
story: It#s been three and a half years since the UK voted to leave the European Union # presumably giving Britons plenty of time to prepare for every doom-laden scenario put forward throughout these tumultuous times.But after countless political fallouts, three deadline extensions and two general elections, Britain # including the Remain-voting Scotland # will withdraw from the bloc on January .Some have stockpiled goods and utilities ahead of the event, amid predictions of chaos at borders leading to supply shortages of food and medicines. Meanwhile the UK Government, led by Boris Johnson, has busied itself trying to convince taxpayers to raise Â£, in order to make the currently out of commission Big Ben ring again on #Brexit Day#.But what about ordinary Dundonians on the street â€“ have punters really been that worried about the upcoming split â€œIâ€™ve done no preparation at all,â€ said Val King, an admin assistant from Forfar.â€œIt has come round quite quickly. I think everyone will be much the same theyâ€™ve been busy with Christmas, and this has just been ongoing the whole time.â€œYouâ€™ve had this thing about Big Ben, which has been absolutely ridiculous. What a waste of money.â€œYou only have to look around and see how many people there are on the streets to know the money could be better spent.â€Alex Simpson, , an art student at DJCAD, said: â€œI wasnâ€™t old enough to vote at the time of the vote so people my age didnâ€™t get a chance to have a say.â€œItâ€™ll just be a case of seeing what happens. I donâ€™t think anyone can really believe itâ€™s happening though.â€œI really donâ€™t think it will make much dference to peopleâ€™s day-to-day lives, theyâ€™ll still get up and go about their day the same.â€Monica Anderson, a retired council worker from Dundee, admits sheâ€™s still uncertain as to whether Brexit will actually take place.But she is hopeful it does â€“ even though she was a remain voter in .Monica said: â€œIâ€™m still waiting on it actually happening. Iâ€™m still doubtful it will actually happen because it has dragged on so long â€“ but I would like to see it happen.â€œI voted remain before, but I donâ€™t want Scotland to become independent from the UK so I would like to see Brexit happen.â€œI donâ€™t think we should held hostage by politicians in Brussels. If there was another vote I would vote leave again.â€œI would say people are fed up â€“ by now it is either going to happen or itâ€™s not.â€Sandy Robertson, , a former jute factory worker from Forfar, was less optimistic â€“ and thinks leaving the EU is a mistake.He said: â€œI still think we should remain. Things should just be left the way they are. I think the English voters made a mistake when they voted to leave and weâ€™re just having to put up with it.â€œIt wasnâ€™t Scottish voters who voted to leave.â€œI think there were a lot of people in the farming and fishing industries who influenced people to vote leave as well.â€œItâ€™s just been a big mess that weâ€™ve been dragged into against our will.â€Earlier this month city councillors approved the latest recommendations put forward by officers to prepare DundeeÂ  for Brexit.In his report before the councilâ€™s policy and resources committee, chief executive David Martin warned that Brexit continued to hold â€œsignicant financial and operational risksâ€ for the council.He wrote: â€œBoth the Cross Party European Group and the officersâ€™ Brexit Advisory Team have continued to meet regularly to consider the risks facing the council and the city in order to make any preparations possible.â€œStaff in frontline services across the council, including libraries and community centres, as well across our community planning partners, have been briefed and given a handout to support and signpost citizens.â€œIn addition, we have worked with Dundee and Angus Chamber of Commerce to promote the scheme to their members and ensured welfare rights advice services across the city are briefed.#He said that the chamber had also recruited additional staff resources to support export documentation and to assist in wider preparedness work.In addition to that, elected members had been given information in case constituents raised queries via their surgeries.Mr Martin said: â€œDundeeâ€™s Central Library is a location for the Assisted Digital Scheme for those needing help to make online applications, and we are also publicising the assistance available locally from the Citizens Advice Bureau.â€œThe Children and Families Service and the Health and Social Care Partnership have been made aware of responsibilities for applications on behalf of looked after children and vulnerable adults.â€He said that the impact on servicesthe council#s workforce was reduced as EU nationals left the country was low.Â  but that the authority had sought to re-assure those affected that we want them and their families to stay, and to signpost them to information and support.â€

title: callachan aiming to end below par east end record with dark blues
story: East End Park is a venue Ross Callachan is no stranger to.In his six years in the Raith Rovers first-team, he took part in the Fe derby four times, twice in Dunfermline.On neither occasion, however, was the -year-old able to end up on the winning side.But Callachan is hoping to change all that tonight when he heads there as a Dundee player after joining on loan until the end of the season from St Johnstone last week.The Pars are on a poor run of form themselves, losing their last five in the league.However, Callachan insists that counts for nothing and all the Dark Blues can focus on is doing whatâ€™s required to earn all three points after the disappointment of exiting the cup to Motherwell in his debut last weekend.â€œIâ€™ve played them a few times home and away but itâ€™s always tough going to East End,â€ he said.â€œTheyâ€™ll be looking to win, losing their last five games, so I think itâ€™s a must-win for both teams.â€œIt was disappointing to be out of the cup but at least we can focus on the league now.â€œWe have  games left until the end of the season so, hopefully, we can go and push for the play-offs.â€Callachan is realistic, however, and knows the pitfalls of the Championship from his time at Raith.With just four points separating Dundee in fourth and the Fers in fth, he hopes to draw on all his experience to help the Dee in this one and every game after.â€œItâ€™s very tough. I think in this league teams can be inconsistent and, probably, Dundee have been like that themselves throughout this season,â€ he added.â€œHopefully, I can come and help that. Iâ€™ve been in the league before with Raith and in the play-offs, too. Iâ€™ve been there and done it all before.â€Although keen to kick on and help the Dark Blues this term, Callachan is just happy to be playing again after enduring a long spell out of the team at Saints.He only made four appearances for the Perth men this season, the last coming in September, and is enjoying feeling wanted again.â€œIâ€™m hungry to play, do well and help the team,â€ he said defiantly.â€œI want to get games under my belt because it was frustrating at St Johnstone.â€œYouâ€™re sitting in the stands and you feel you can help the team but the manager thought otherwise.â€œIâ€™m just happy somebody wants me here and I feel like Iâ€™ve fitted in right away.â€œHopefully, I can go and play and show what I can do.â€œThe initial attraction was Dundee were interested in me. My head was turned right away.â€œObviously, not playing at St Johnstone made me want to come here.â€œThe plan is to help the club get to where it wants to be, back in the Premiership.â€œWeâ€™re in the play-off spots now so, hopefully, we push and climb up to second.â€œDundee United are going to win the league so the main thing for us is getting to the play-offs and going up that way.â€œWe want to finish as high as possible.â€Playing alongside and learning from quality players like Graham Dorrans is another reason why Callachan was happy to make the switch up the A, across Tayside.And he was delighted to see his team-mate sign a new deal this week.â€œHeâ€™s, obviously, played at a right high level and you can tell heâ€™s a good player who can help the team.â€œHim signing a new deal can only be good for us.â€œItâ€™s good for everyone we have that competition.â€œItâ€™s good for the club and for the boys, competition is always good.â€

title: clean rabbies napper teles call to dundee city council to get bird dirt off statues head
story: Scotland#s national bard will be celebrated across the world tomorrow but the Tele has issued one demand to the city council ahead of Burns Night: Clean Rabbie#s napper.The Robert Burns monument, which can be found outside the McManus galleries, has stood in the city since  and is a symbol of pride for many in both Scotland and Dundee.It is one of four identical statues commemorating the Scotsman across the world, with the others being found in Dunedin, New York and London.However, the effigy has fallen victim to attacks from above in recent years, with seagulls and pigeons leaving droppings on the poor bard#s head.The sorry state of the statue has encouraged the Tele to make a stand and demand Rabbie is shown the respect he deserves.An offer to send a Tele reporter up to clean it ourselves was rebuffed by council chiefs # so now it#s up to the local authority to have it gleaming again.Many Dundonians agree with our view and Cullen Armstrong, , who works part-time at Thorton#s Law, said: #It just needs people with a scrubbing brush to go up and give it a good clean.#I don#t know how you#d protect it from the birds, but it definitely needs a good clean.#Connor Ferguson, a -year-old security consultant from the Hilltown, also believes the poet#s likeness could do with a bit of a clean up.He said: #Well obviously it needs the bird droppings cleaned off it.#It could do with a bit more care and attention, so it looks good for all the tourists that are coming into the city.#Hilltown resident Simon Young, a -year-old therapist, said: #I was just thinking that it wasn#t looking its best.#It absolutely could do with a clean. Dundee is a nice city with lots of nice statues.#It would be good for them all to get a bit of attention and get nice and clean.#However, some believe that cleaning up the poet#s head might not be worth the hassle.Lynn Dignan, , a retired Asda worker from Craigie, said: #I don#t think he really needs a clean-up.#We#re pretty used to him looking like that honestly.#The money and time they would need to clean it could go to a lot of things which are more important.#Dundee City Council has been contacted for comment.

title: dundee united 2 2 hibs appere solo goal earns united cup replay
story: Louis Appere earned Dundee United a Scottish Cup fourth-round replay as they twice came from behind to draw with Hibs.Christian Doidge gave the Hibees a dream start after eight minutes at Tannadice before Lawrence Shankland scored a classy equaliser in first-half stoppage time.Martin Boyle put the visitors back in front with a powerful drive on  minutes before substitute Appere curled home a leveller on  minutes which earned the Terrors an Easter Road replay and a place in the hat for the last- draw.United showed five changes from the team which faced Partick last weekend with Jamie Robson, Calum Butcher, Ian Harkes, Peter Pawlett and Paul McMullan coming in for Adrian Sporle, Declan Glass, Nicky Clark, Louis Appere and Mark Reynolds.It was Pawlett#s first start for almost three months, with McMullan and Harkes seeing their first action since the last Dundee derby.What had been billed as the tie of the round got off to a frenetic start. And it was the visitors who almost took the lead after three minutes. However, Mark Connolly was in the right place at the right time to clear Florian Kamberi#s effort off the line.Hibs weren#t to be denied five minutes later, though, as they opened the scoring through a low Doidge effort. Slipped in by former Dundee man Boyle, the Welsh hitman coolly slotted under Benjamin Siegrist for -.On  minutes, straight from a United corner, the Hibees broke. Boyle was again the creator-in-chief, with his surging run into the Terrors# half leaving United back pedalling before Melker Hallberg saw his shot foiled by Siegrist.Kamberi again fired towards his fellow-countryman just before the half-hour but this time it was an easy save for United#s Swiss stopper.The Tangerines were struggling to get a foothold in the match and had created few chances as proceedings approached the half-way point. When Liam Smith found Harkes at the edge of the box to fire in a fairly innocuous shot, however, the mood seemed to lt around Tannadice.On  minutes, Siegrist again halted a deflected Kamberi effort from a matter of yards as the Hibees continued to press. United were starting to enjoy more possession, though, and went in at half-time with the tie level thanks to Shankland#s th domestic goal of the season.In the last of three minutes of added time at the end of the first period, Harkes strolled through the heart of the Hibs defence before sliding in Shankland to slot home from eight yards despite being under heavy pressure.United weren#t level for long, though, as two minutes into the second period the men from Edinburgh were back in the lead.Scott Allan played provider as he laid in Boyle to drive home low beyond an outstretched Siegrist from fully  yards.Kamberi#s battle with Siegrist continued on  minutes with the goalie again denying the striker#s thunderbolt from distance with the rebound just evading Boyle on the follow-up.Allan fired over just after the hour as the Terrors, again, fell out of the game as boss Robbie Neilson ordered their first change of the afternoon, sending Appere on for Pawlett.And young attacker Appere had the desired impact  minutes after coming on, picking up possession on the left before twisting and turning away from Steven Whittaker and then David Gray to curl a delightful effort beyond the helpless Ofir Marciano for -.Both teams pushed for a winner in the closing  minutes, with Siegrist pulling off a top save from Doidge in injury time, but it never came, meaning these two will have to do it all again a week on Tuesday in the capital.Dundee United : Siegrist , Smith, Watson, Connolly, Robson Harkes , Butcher , Powers McMullan, Shankland, Pawlett .Subs not used: Deniz, Sporle, Reynolds, Sow and King.Hibs : Marciano , Naismith , Porteous , Hanlon , Stevenson Hallberg, Allan, Whittaker Boyle, Doidge, Kamberi.Subs: Bogdan , Slivka, Newell, Horgan and Shaw.Ref: Kevin Clancy.Att: ,.

story: Graham Dorrans has signed a new -month contract at Dundee.The -year-old midfielder originally joined the Dark Blues from Rangers in September on a deal until the end of the season.Dorrans had been linked with a move to English side MK Dons earlier in the January transfer window. title: midfielder scott banks leaves dundee united for crystal palace
story: Young midfielder Scott Banks has left Dundee United for English Premier League side Crystal Palace.The -year-old was a Tangerines youth academy product and made four first-team appearances this season after impressing on loan at Clyde.Suitors started circling in the summer, with Palace at the front of the pack chasing the Scotland U  international, and a three-year deal has now been confirmed.United has offered the teenager a deal but he, his family and representatives have decided a switch to the London club would be the best move for him at this stage of his career.United are thought to be owed at least Â£, in training compensation as part of the deal.United sporting director Tony Asghar said: â€œEveryone here wishes Scott all the best for his future career.â€œHe is someone who has developed in our academy from an early age and we made him a good offer to remain and continue his development at United.#It is clear that a move to an English Premier League club has proved very attractive for Scott, his family, and his representatives to turn down.â€œI believe Scott has the ability to become a top talent in football and hope that he continues to develop to the level we believe he could have progressed to had he chosen to remain at Dundee United.â€Banks said: â€œThereâ€™s no bigger stage Iâ€™d want to play on . Itâ€™s a big step up coming from Scotland.â€œWhen you hear about that interest , you want to pursue that, and push myself to the highest level. So it was a no-brainer that this was the place for me.â€

title: vandalism at dundee technology park slammed as mindless by workers
story: Business owners at Dundee Technology Park have hit out at the #mindless vandalism# which has seen vehicles in their car park being targeted.Police are investigating after a black Hyundai i was broken into in Greystane Terrace, Invergowrie but nothing was taken from the car.Three male youths in their late teens were seen running off towards Dundee and the Technology Park shortly after.Vandalism was then carried out on four cars parked in Luna Place, four parked in Gemini Crescent, and a further six in Wurzburg Place.A black Peugeot  parked in Mariner Drive was also broken into and property was stolen from it.The police are linking all the incidents and believe there could be even more affected.Richard Hanlon, owner of Mortgage Planners, said: #I found a car this morningand saw the window was broken.#It#s a bit of a shock to see this, but it has been happening for more than a week now.#I saw the one today about am, which was a white car, maybe a Ford Fiesta, with a window smashed.#At first I thought the window had been rolled down but then as I came closer I saw there was no one about and the glass in the inside.#Margaret Dye, manager of mortgage firm Clark Thompson, said: #It used to be a nice place but now we have had all this and there have been two or three cars hit since last Friday.#We heard that there had been  cars that had windows smashed in the technology park in the last couple of weeks. It#s awful.#Two more workers from another firm declined to be named, but one man said: #Our company car was hit again this morning . We heard a nurses agency had cars smashed and another office window was broken. I don#t think anything was taken.#His colleague added: #It is mindless vandalism and absolute nonsense. It impacts on the whole area.#Police are now searching for those responsible and a statement said: #Police Scotland is appealing for information about an extensive series of vandalisms and car break-ins in Invergowrie and the Dundee Technology Park which happened between pm-midnight last night .#If you have any information that could assist our investigation, particularlyyou saw this group of three young men in the area last night, please call  or speak with any police officer. Also, information can be passed anonymously through Crimestoppers on   . Our reference is incident  of January .#

story: Aberdeen have signed winger Matty Kennedy from St Johnstone on a three-and-a-half year contract until summer .The -year-old goes straight into contention to make his Dons debut in Sunday#s Premiership trip to St Mirren .Kennedy had already agreed a pre-contract to join the Dons in the summer.However, Aberdeen manager Derek McInnes wanted to secure the Northern Ireland international squad player six months earlier to solve a lack of pace and creativity evident in recent games.Aberdeen pushed through a deal to land Kennedy in the January transfer windowÂ  in a deal understood to be for Â£, plus add-ons.His signing was completed at Pittodrie tonight.Capped at every level from youth to U by Scotland, Kennedy recently switched allegiance to Northern Ireland when called into a recent squad.The former Everton, Kilmarnock and Cardf City play-maker has started  times for Saints this season, scoring five times.Crucially he is not cup tied for the Scottish Cup having missed the defeat of Morton at the weekend due to a knock.Kennedy is the second major signing secured by McInnes during the January window having secured midfielder Dylan McGeouch from Sunderland.Teenage midfielder Mark Gallagher was signed from Ross County but he is for the development squad.Atlanta United attacker Jon Gallagher also extended his loan deal from the American MLS side until the end of the season.

story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site isÂ  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowLooking back over the last  months, no single story has dominated the headlines in these pages, but there have been important themes.There are the negative trends, of course.
