title: Marianne Taylor  Megxit - the scary post-Brexit home truths
story: Clearly, Harry and Meghan arenrsquot so much stepping back from royal le as checking out completely, with a flick of the Vs that could be taken to signy peace, victory or what those of us fluent in Parliamo Glasgow would recognise as ldquoget it up ye.:Harry and Meghan will not use HRH titles or get royal funds - palaceSafe to say I wonrsquot be spending too much time fretting over the future happiness of this super-rich celebrity couple. But I do wish them well, especially since the completely OTT reaction to their decision tells you everything you need to know about why they had the good sense to pack it all in the first place."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Harry and Meghan: Key dates in the Megxit crisis","description": "Harry and Meghan: Key dates in the Megxit crisis","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media qDexymFG poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests qDexymFG.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": More importantly, however, the wider fallout from the Sussex move tells us much about the general state of post-Brexit Britain. And it ainrsquot pretty. In fact, itrsquos getting downright scary, especially as every week the narrative seems to sht closer to the isive and damaging - but also very deliberate - culture wars being waged in Trumprsquos America.We witnessed this first hand over the last couple of weeks with the grim spectacle of groups of well-spoken middle class white men, mostly of a certain age, being rounded up and brought into television studios to sit on sofas next to black women and explain to them not only what racism is and is not, but also why theirlived experiences of it are worthless. And, when the women speakers pointed out the irony and injustice of this set-up  Calm down dear, yoursquore getting hysterical.Question Time provided perhaps the most eye-watering example of this when actor Lawrence Fox - who had been invited to sit in the ldquovoice of the people chair - unleashed a shocking but very revealing attack on a mixed-race member of the audience who suggested Meghan Marklersquos treatment by the media and others had been racist.:The curse of the House of Windsor: how love has torn apart the royal familyMr Fox, a Harrow-educated member of an established acting dynasty known for his role in the detective series Lewis, tore into the woman - who it turns out is an academic researcher in race and ethnicity - talking over her, aggressively calling the suggestion of racism ldquoboring, adding imperiously: ldquoWersquore the mostly tolerant, lovely country in the world." The actor compounded matters by using the tired and predictable ldquoyoursquore the racist defence when quite reasonably questioned on how a spfing white chap like him could be so sure about what racism is and is not.:Netflix chief confirms interest in deal with Harry and MeghanI donrsquot doubt that from Mr Foxrsquos privileged perch, Britain is indeed tolerant and lovely. It is certainly still tolerant of and shockingly reverent towards posh types like him who ignorantly and arrogantly skip through le with a wealthy family to pick them upthings donrsquot go their way. Laughably, most of the similar types Irsquove met in le honestly believe they earn their opportunities on merit.The ennui of privilege, eh  They tend to be bored with uppity totty of all races, of course. Theyrsquore probably terribly fed up with feckless poor people banging on about foodbanks, and moany, chippy Jocks, too.Itrsquos the soaring confidence of such attacks and pronouncements that really concerns me, however, the increasingly loud and proud tone of them, the whf of US right-wing s like Fox News, Breitbart and One American News Network.Indeed, rather than apologising or stepping back from his embarrassingly outburst on Question Time, Mr Fox, who has been roundly criticised by his profession, saw fit to launch a defence of his actions, including a barrage of mocking, wince-inducing tweets packed with right-wing US tropes around ldquoliberals and ldquowokeness. Whatrsquos going on  We simply wouldnrsquot have tolerated such behaviour in public  years ago.But with Boris Johnson in Number , a man who defends his writings about ldquopiccaninnies with ldquowater melon smiles, ldquobum boys ldquogirly swats and how voting Tory will ldquogive your we bigger breasts, I suppose such behaviour has both permission and a champion.Make no mistake, the faction of the Tory party that has taken over Britain in the wake of Brexit will revel in and stoke culture wars of this kind. It feels threatened by attacks on pale, male stale dominance, of course. But such isiveness also works as the ultimate distraction technique, stealing our focus away from the deliberate running down of public services, the re-writing of the social contract.And so far itrsquos working a treat.

title: Iain Macwhirter  Scotland could rejoin the EU  but would it want to
story: But fear not, because Nicola Sturgeon says we can rejoin whenever we want. All we need to do is vote for independence. Wersquod be back in the European fold before you can say bing bang bong. So, is it as easy as she says it is Well, letrsquos get Project Fear out of the way first. There is every reason to believe that an independent Scotland would be fast-tracked back into the European Union. Talk of Scotland being held indefinitely in a holding pen with Turkey, North Macedonia and Albania is ridiculous. These are countries with awkward human rights and unresolved economic issues."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Brexit:  days until Britain is scheduled to leave the EU","description": "Brexit:  days until Britain is scheduled to leave the EU","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media QVXJzBe poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests QVXJzBe.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": Scotland is a stable democracy, with an impeccable human rights record, a dynamic and flexible economy and prodigious natural resources. No, we donrsquot have a high-value economy any more, like Irelandrsquos or Norwayrsquos, largely because of being a backwater in the UK for the last half century. But Scotland could still offer the national income of Portugal with the population of Slovakia.:Nicola Sturgeon to set out plan for Scottish independence referendum next weekSo, we can forget the  nonsense about going to the end of the queue or being blocked by Spain. There is now a reservoir of goodwill, especially in the European Parliament, following Scotlandrsquos determined resistance to Brexit. Wersquod be back in, probably within - years according to Kirsty Hughes of the Scottish Centre on European Relations.However, there is one small problem. Scotland would have to be fully independent first. Unless Scotland has a referendum in this transition year there is no longer any prospect of Scotland, as it were, remaining in the European Union as rUK leaves. We may still be under the same regulatory environment as Europe in the transition period, but donrsquot think that can just be extended as in Northern Ireland.Mentioning the Irish backstop is not the way to get a sympathetic hearing in the European Union. Many states are unhappy about Northern Ireland being allowed to remain, effectively, in the European single market without being part of the EU or the EEA.It breaks all the rules. And Scotland can forget about being given similar treatment. Speaking to Brussels officials this week confirms that there will be no read-across to Scotland from the Northern Ireland protocol. They wonrsquot even discuss it.So, there is no half way house. Scotland needs to take the leap into full independence. That means having a central bank and an autonomous currency before Scotland could become a candidate for accession. There are two problems here, but they arenrsquot insurmountable.Scotland would have to formally agree to the Maastricht Treaty, and membership of the euro. It is most unlikely that Scotland would get a formal opt-out from the euro, but it could drag its feet for a very long time, like Sweden. Whether Scotland would want to is another matter. Euro membership has worked well for many small countries.A more dficult issue is convergence. Scotland would have to show that its economy meets the terms of the stability pact, which means having a deficit of less than three per cent. At present, according to the GERS figures, Scotland has a deficit of more than twice that.However, after independence these numbers would almost certainly change. There will be a lot of fiscal give and take between Scotland and the rest of the UK over assets and liabilities.But Scotland would have to show that it is capable of harnessing its currency to the euro, evenit doesnrsquot actually join it. Currency autonomy might be hard to establish , as in the Scottish Governmentrsquos scenario, Scotland keeps using the pound for a decade after independence.: In post-Brexit Britain, Nicola Sturgeon cant keep telling her troops that Indyref is round the corner. It isntIf a nominally independent Scotland were still subject to interest rates operating in a country that is outside the European Union, that would be a dficult sell. The EU is very good at finding novel ways to get round problems like this. But it might take a few years.There may be a trade deal on regulations between the UK and the EU that solves some of Scotlandrsquos accession and border problems. We just donrsquot know. This is one of the imponderables of Scottish independence. It is actually very dficult to make a clear prospectus for indyref when we donrsquot yet know how the UK is going to stand in relation to the EU.But there is a bigger question than all of these: would Scotland necessarily want to rejoin the European Union  Nicola Sturgeon takes it as read, but there would be a debate at the very least. Around a million Scots voted for Brexit and many of them were supporters of independence.Brussels has had some bad press in the last decade. Austerity policies were imposed after  which were worse than in the UK and caused problems across the Mediterranean states. Its behaviour toward Greece during the sovereign debt crisis would have shamed the British Empire at its worst.Brussels stood idly by while one member state, Spain, imposed draconian repression in Catalonia, breaking heads and locking up elected politicians. There was scarcely a word from Brussels, let alone sanctions. Then there is fish.Many in the independence movement believe the EU is a neoliberal club ndash which it is ndash and would be happier with an arrangement like Norwayrsquos which has control of fishing grounds, is not subject to EU rules and has a managed economy. The case for a referendum before Scotland rejoined the EU would seem to me to be unanswerable.At the very least, the SNP could not take it for granted. Unionists will continue to argue that it makes little economic sense for Scotland to leave the Union with the UK, which is where the majority of Scottish exports go. There would be a hard border, currency controls, possibly tarfs.Ms Sturgeonrsquos problem is that the very arguments the SNP used against leaving the European Union ndash freedom of movement, zero tarfs, regulatory harmony ndash apply equally to leaving the United Kingdom. Theyrsquoll come winging back. Aversion to Boris Johnson may not be enough to persuade Scots to take the biggest leap in  years.Read more: Sturgeon cant keep telling her troops that Indyref is round the corner

title: coronavirus-14-people-tested-uk-five-negative-nine-await-results
story: Fourteen people were tested for the virus, with five confirmed negative and nine still awaiting results, Public Health Englandsaid on Thursday night.The Scottish Government had earlier confirmed that five people were being examined after presenting with symptoms of the illness, while it was understood that another patient was being tested at Belfastrsquos Royal Victoria Hospital.:Helen McArdle: It is disappointing to see more evidence of bias, conflicts of interest and hidden data in sciencePHE would not give a breakdown of where the people were tested and where the negative results were recorded.While none of the UK cases has been confirmed as the virus so far, two of those being tested in Scotland had been diagnosed with influenza after travelling to Wuhan, China.They all travelled to Scotland from Wuhan, where the outbreak is thought to have originated, within the past two weeks, and were showing symptoms of respiratory trouble, a red flag for the virus.Downing Street said four suspected cases in Scotland were believed to involve Chinese nationals.It comes after infections expert Professor Jurgen Haas claimed there would likely be ldquomany more cases around the country, while Health Secretary Matt Hancock said the NHS is ldquoready to respond appropriately to any cases that emerge in the UK.In a statement to the Commons on Thursday, Mr Hancock said while ldquothere is an increased likelihood that cases may arise in this country, we are well prepared and well equipped to deal with them.Also on Thursday, the World Health Organisationsaid it is ldquotoo early to declare an international public health emergency over the outbreak ldquogiven its restrictive and binary nature.Speaking at a press conference, Dr Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, director-general of the WHO, said: ldquoMake no mistake, this is though an emergency in China.ldquoBut it has not yet become a global health emergency.ldquoIt may yet become one.He said  cases have been reported to the WHO, including  deaths, with  of the overall cases and all the deaths reported in China.Other cases have been reported in Japan, South Korea, Singapore, Thailand, the US and Vietnam.Dr Tedros said: ldquoWe know that most of those who have died had underlying health conditions such as hypertension, diabetes or cardiovascular disease, that weakened their immune systems.:Coronavirus: Too early to declare public health emergencyldquoWe know that there is human-to-human transmission in China, but for now it appears limited to family groups and health workers caring for infected patients.ldquoAt this time, there is no evidence of human-to-human transmission outside China, but that doesnrsquot mean it wonrsquot happen.ldquoThere is still a lot we donrsquot know. We donrsquot know the source of this virus, we donrsquot understand how easily it spreads and we donrsquot fully understand its clinical features or severity.Peter Piot, professor of global health and director of the London School of Hygiene  Tropical Medicine, said there were still ldquomany missing pieces in the jigsaw puzzle, adding: ldquoOver the coming days and weeks we will know much more, but there cannot be any complacency as to the need for global action.ldquoThe good news is that the data to date suggest that this virus may have a lower mortality than Sars, we have a diagnostic test and there is greater transparency than decades gone by.The full statement by @DrTedros on IHR Emergency Committee on new #coronavirus #https:t.co BOapDyKPW pic vjuUzLaEomdash World Health Organization January , ldquoAnd that is essential because you cannot deal with a potential pandemic in one country alone.Prof Haas, head of infection medicine at the University of Edinburgh, told the PA news agency on Thursday: ldquoWe have currently three cases of suspected Wuhan coronavirus in Edinburgh and as far as I understand one case in Glasgow.He said the cases emerged overnight, adding:ldquoThe situation will be pretty similar in pretty much all UK cities with a large number of Chinese students.ldquoItrsquos not too surprising. My suspicion is that there will probably be many more cases in many other cities in the UK.ldquoNone of the cases I know of have been confirmed.He said there was only one laboratory testing for the virus, operated by Public Health England .The professor said the cases had been flagged up through the PHE infection guidelines, as they travelled to Wuhan within the last  days and were showing signs of respiratory symptoms.The Chinese government has effectively locked down Wuhan, cancelling planes and trains there and in the nearby city of Huanggang.

title: mark-smith-views-lgb-alliance-worrying---far-extreme
story: In the past, I have been thrown out of nightclubs. One time, it was because I caused a scene over a stolen jacket, but usually, it was because I was drunk and being a bit of an ****. One thing I can say, though, is that Irsquove never been thrown out of a nightclub because of my beliefs.But this is what appears to have happened at the Polo Lounge in Glasgow. The Polo is a LGBT venue in the centre of town, and according to a video on social media, a woman was kicked out of the club recently for wearing a T-shirt bearing the logo ldquoLGB Alliance. Some people are said to have complained the T-shirt was anti-trans and the woman was told to turn it inside-out or she would have to leave.The womanrsquos reaction to the situation was pretty much the reaction of everyone whorsquos ever been kicked out of a club: it wasnrsquot me. ldquoIrsquove just been removed, she said, ldquobecause trans people, who I didnrsquot even see, said I was threatening to them... Donrsquot I have the right to support lesbians, gays and bisexuals  Trans people, she went on, had the power to have her kicked out because they didnrsquot like an acronym on a T-shirt.:We must fight against the rolling back of trans rightsI realise the street outside a nightclub in the early hours of the morning is not the best place for nuance, but I wish we had more subtlety in this debate. My sympathy ndash instinctively and empirically ndash is with the nightclub I am a supporter of the right of trans people to identy their gender and to have all the rights of that gender. But I also dislike the idea of people who do not agree with a particular view being excluded from a public place.That said, I understand why many LGBT people dislike the LGB Alliance. Take their horrible website for a start. Therersquos nothing critics of trans reform seem to love more than pictures of trans women who do not ldquopass as women, which may explain why the LGB Alliance website is full of pictures of beautul, thin people and women who conform to traditional feminine images ndash they ldquolook like women in other words.Therersquos an unpleasant air of supremacy about the pictures and they make me deeply uncomfortable.Some of the language on the site is also worrying. I was speaking to Michael Cashman, the co-founder of Stonewall, the other day, and, although we didnrsquot talk about the Glasgow case specically, what he said on trans rights was interesting. Young peoplersquos attitudes to gender are in advance of older peoplersquos, he said, but he also believes some of the ways in which trans people have been portrayed are similar to the way gay men used to be portrayed ndash as a threat to children for example. ldquoDangerous to children is a phrase that appears on the LGB website, along with multiple uses of the word ldquothreat. We have been here before.The fact that some gay people have signed up to the LGB Alliance does not change its flaws.They do not explain, for instance, in what way the right to self-identication is a ldquomortal threat to gay rights. They also do not appear to acknowledge that legislating for equality involves a balancing of rights and risks. And they certainly do not explain on whose authority they seek to remove the T from LGBT. They do not have that right.: Scotland can learn lessons from Canada on trans best practiceIrsquom not saying their views are extreme ndash far from it, opposition to trans equality is not an unusual opinion, which is why we should take a nuanced view of the woman who was thrown out of Polo.What she was doing was insensitive and many people will have found her shirt offensive and unpleasant, but in Britain you are allowed to be insensitive, offensive and unpleasantyou want to be.My advice to the woman, had she asked me, would have been to get over herself and not to go to a gay bar wearing that shirt, because why would you want to upset people in a place where they feel safe But my advice to the club would have been to let her stay. Anyone who goes to a gay bar and claims therersquos no T in LGBT is being insensitive and provocative, but the gay bar can be better.It can say: we are a liberal, mature and progressive place we are tolerant and we tolerate even you.

title: jeanie-smoking-cigarette-love-loss
story: Maybe wersquod have gone out for a meal or gone to the movies. You loved the movies. You werenrsquot fussy. At some point Irsquod have kissed you and told you I loved you, like I did every other day.But not this birthday. Not this year. For the first time since  I wonrsquot be able to do any of that.Ah, Jeanie.My we Jean died on October  last year at .am in Strathcarron Hospice. Outside, birds were singing.Shersquod been in the hospice for a couple of days. On the Thursday it had reached the point where I was no longer able to look after her properly at home.I had spent the Friday night trying to sleep in a chair beside her bed. Every so often Irsquod lean over and talk to her as she slept, letting her know I was there. Or so I hoped. The voice gets through, one of the hospice nurses had told me.Just after eight her breathing changed. It began to slow and slow as I held her hand and cried. And then it stopped.Such a strangely peaceful thing, I remember thinking in between the tears. Nothing traumatic. Just a sht into stillness.An ending, one that had been waiting for us since she was first diagnosed with breast cancer in .Shards of memory from that morning keep coming back to me. They still cut me open. The face of the nurse I spoke to earlier that morning as the enormity of what was ahead of me was finally sinking in the same nurse who came through the door  minutes later when Jean stopped breathing. The drive down the hill to Denny knowing that I had to tell Jeanrsquos mother and sisters, our daughters, what had happened.And then the drive back. The final moments we spent with her, all the words we didnrsquot get to sayunspoken.I am writing this three-and-a-half months later. No time at all. An eternity.Most mornings I reach across the bed to where she should be, where she isnrsquot. I go through each day knowing that the person I have loved most in this world is no longer in it.I want to hear her say my name one last time. I have been trying to remember the last time she did. Somewhere in the couple of weeks before she died, I guess, before illness took language away from her. A last time that I didnrsquot realise would be the last.The thing I struggle to get my head around is the way she is somehow everywhere and nowhere now. Every road I drive down, every song I hear on the radio, she is in them. Everything is a trigger, everything points to once-insignicant memories now charged and potent, small moments from the past suddenly weighed down with an impossible weight of loss and longing.I have nothing original or unique to say about grief. Irsquom sorry. No eloquence, no insight. Mostly itrsquos a drudge illuminated by spikes of pain.The truth is, I suspect Irsquom still only in the foothills anyway. I cry most days. Sometimes I prompt it deliberately bring her to mind in a way I know will hurt, like sticking a needle into an open wound, just to remind myself that Irsquom feeling something.Other times I try to distract myself. Football on the radio, bad movies on the telly, books that seem a safe distance from her memory.But griefrsquos a sneaky f***er. Last week I was reading a passage in a book about starfish. My subconscious made the connection for me. From starfish I thought of the word seahorse and suddenly I remembered Jeaniersquos tattoo, little black ribbons and bars of ink in the shape of a cartoon-cute seahorse.And, in the same moment, I realised that I hadnrsquot thought about it since she died. How was that even possible  Was it on her left arm or her right arm  Suddenly I wasnrsquot sure. was the cruellest year. On the last day of  we were told we had run out of treatments. In May we were told Jeanie had, at best, a few months. Before we left, I remember, her oncologist gave her a hug.How did we get through the rest of that day  Itrsquos a blank to me now.Weeks passed. Irsquod repeat my mantra to her most days. ldquoYoursquore okay today, so things are okay. I was in a state of deep denial. Jeanie knew better.By July and August it was clear that her illness was beginning to have a real impact. She began to lose memory and speech. It seemed a final cruel punishment for someone so articulate, so engaged with the world. The last weeks were marked by her slow withdrawal from all of us, a withdrawal that became final on that October morning.Three-and-a-half months ago. No time at all. An eternity.ldquoNo tenses any more, the poet Denise Riley writes in Time Lived, Without its Flow, her essay about grief in the wake of the sudden death of her son. ldquoHis sudden death has dropped like a guillotine blade to slice through my old expectation that my days would stream onwards into my coming le. Instead, I continue to sense my daily le as paper-thin. As it is. But this cut through any usual feeling of chronology leaves a great blankness ahead.No tenses any more. In truth, we both had been living in a continuous present for years, ever since Jean was first diagnosed. The first mention of the word cancer cut away the notion of a future.She was diagnosed in the autumn. ldquoIrsquoll not see Christmas, she told me then. We saw another . But even so the future, or the idea of it at least, had been taken from us, even as we grew older and watched our kids grow up.Worse, the past had been taken from us as well. It was too painful for her to think about. Even everyday intimacies and nothing-special moments were out of bounds. We had the present and nothing . And now I donrsquot even have that. I am already living in that great blankness that Riley talks about.That said, maybe I have the past again. I can revisit it. And I do.Most days I find myself fantasising about going back in time, inserting myself into a moment we once shared. It doesnrsquot have to be anything special. Just as long as we are together, where I can hear her voice, where I can see her face, where I can touch her arm, her cheek, know that she is there with me. Given the choice right now, I would live forever in that moment. Reliving it again and again.In some ways I already am. Just before Christmas I had our wedding video transferred to DVD so I could watch it. I donrsquot think I had ever watched it before,Irsquom honest. Now I canrsquot stop.Itrsquos not really a wedding video, just some footage my friend Mark filmed that day back in . Watching it again took me back to our old flat in Bruce Street, Stirling. There are our two cats, my sister-in-law looking impossibly young, my dad, Jeaniersquos dad, now no longer with us. And here are friends who have drted out of our lives.But, really, when I watch it, Irsquom only watching Jeanie. She would have been  when it was filmed. God, she looks beautul. She had her make-up done professionally that morning and she hated it. And yet on video itrsquos clear how great it looks on her.She hated being filmed. It explains why she hardly says anything in the video. That was not like her at all. I wish she had said more on camera, just so I can hear her speak. But the fact that she is there is enough, occupying a space in this world, a grainy image of her physical presence that is now out of touch.Already there is a moment in the video I find myself waiting for every time I put it on. At one point she comes through the swing doors that separated our kitchenette from the living room and, as the camera adjusts to the March light streaming through the window, itrsquos clear she is smoking. Jeanie is smoking.I had almost forgotten. How could I have forgotten  It had been something she had done as long as Irsquod known her.She would give it up a year, maybe  months, later with the same steely self-will she later brought to learning to play guitar or speak Esperanto. A task to be achieved.But in the fuzzy, flickering yellow video light, the image rolling and glitchy with age, she can be seen drawing fumes into her lungs with such obvious pleasure that the sight of it felt like a depth charge in my head, a memory of who she once was, of the girl I first met in a student kitchen in Stirling University in September . We were both  then. She was barefooted and wearing a headscarf because her hairdresser had given her a buzzcut, much to her disgust.She sat there smoking and swearing and talking. She was this leforce. I donrsquot know how  to describe her. She was self-confident and outgoing, all the things I wasnrsquot. I was totally smitten. What she saw in me, I still donrsquot know.In time I realised that we had some things in common. We were both working-class kids in a still largely middle-class environment. She had her own vulnerabilities like everyone . Irsquom not sure what I represented to her, but I was happy to represent something, anything.I asked her out. In the most roundabout of ways. And she said no. And then she said yes. And that was the start of the rest of our lives. We got together, stayed together, grew up, got married, had kids, were happy.In my head there are all these dferent versions of Jeanie the -year-old firebrand, the thirtysomething mother, the dedicated professional , the girl who would get drunk with her dad and her sisters every Hogmanay and start singing Leaving on a Jet Plane. The Jeanie who immersed herself in anything that interested her. The Jeanie who could make you laugh just by the way she looked at you.For a few days after her death I found myself resentful about the last incarnation of Jeanie, the one who increasingly was drting away from us, the one I had been caring for in the last weeks of her le. I loved that version too, of course, but the memory of this last Jeanie was so close, so tight against me, that I couldnrsquot see past her to all the others Irsquod spent the best part of  years with.It took my friends Karina and Michael to put me right. Jean and I had met Karina for a coffee in September just before Karina went back to Buenos Aires to look after her own sick mother. It was a farewell meeting. We all knew it.A few weeks later, after Jeanrsquos funeral, Michael told me what Karina had told him about that day, about how, when I was off where for a few moments, Jeanie had told her that she knew what was happening to her and that she was at peace with it.Hearing that felt like a damn breaking inside me. My viewpoint shted  degrees. Suddenly it came home to me how stoical that last version of Jeanie was, how brave. When she was initially diagnosed in , she had struggled to deal with it. But when it ed in  she refused to give into despair. All she wanted, she said, was to see the end of Game of Thrones. She managed that at least.The thing is she wouldnrsquot want you to know any of this. Jeanie was intensely private. She hated me mentioning her in anything I wrote. And this illness. Well, this was her business. But I guess itrsquos my business now. And what is this business  That Irsquom not sure I know. I do know that over and above losing her Ihave somehow also lost my own sense of self. I was so synced to Jeanie that I am now unfixed, ungrounded. What Irsquove realised in this no time eternity that Irsquom currently living in, is I donrsquot really know what Irsquom for any more.I am still a father and a son and a brother and brother-in-law and a friend . But I navigated through the world with Jean as my lodestar. And now that star has disappeared, and the night is dark.I donrsquot believe in heaven but I have taken to thinking about the possibility of parallel universes. I like the idea that somewhere there is another Jeanie even now. In most of them I guess she would never have met me. Or maybe she met me and didnrsquot like me, or vice versa . But I want to believe she is out there. Somewhere, I hope, Jeanie is smoking a cigarette and enjoying it as much as she does in our wedding video.In the week after Jeanrsquos death we put a notice in the Falkirk Herald. The Philip Larkin line from his poem An Arundel Tomb seemed appropriate: ldquoWhat will survive of us is love. It comes at the end of a poem in which Larkin is trying to suggest otherwise. But I want it to be true.Yesterday would have been your birthday, Jeanie. What survives of you is love. Thatrsquos why this hurts so much. Smoke one for me, darling.If you would like to donate to the Strathcarron Hospice, please visit Jean Jamiesonrsquos In Memory page at www.strathcarronhospice.net inmemoryof jean-jamieson

title: euro-chiefs-sign-brexit-withdrawal-agreement-paving-way-britains-departure-eu-weeks-time
story: Charles Michel and Ursula von der Leyen put their signatures to the document in Brussels after the Queen gave Royal Assent to the legislation implementing the agreement on Thursday.Following the formalities in the Belgian capital, the agreement was being taken to London by diplomatic bag for Boris Johnson to sign. He is due to do so this afternoon in Downing St.The European Parliament is now expected to vote to approve the agreement on Wednesday, paving the way for the UK to leave next Friday, January .It will mark the start of an -month transition period, during which the UK will continue to follow EU rules, before the final break with Brussels at the end of the year.The Prime Minister has said he wants to negotiate a comprehensive free trade deal with the EU by the end of the year.However, Mrs von der Leyen and other senior EU figures have warned the Governments stated intention to end the UKs alignment with EU regulations means it will be impossible to achieve within such a tight timetable.Yet Mr Johnson remains upbeat, insisting Britain can now move forward after years of wrangling over Brexit."At times it felt like we would never cross the Brexit finish line, but weve done it," he said earlier this week. "Now we can put the rancour and ision of the past three years behind us and focus on delivering a bright, exciting future," he added.

title: unspun-political-diary
story: RUM doings at Michelle Ballantynersquos launch for the Scottish Tory leadership. Hacks were told to gather in a converted church, presumably because she hasnrsquot a prayer. Asked why no other MSP was backing her, Ms B claimed theyrsquod all pledged allegiance to Jackson Carlaw first because ldquothey didnrsquot know that I was even going to be running two weeksrsquo ago. What jolly rotten luck, eh  Then again, as Ruth Davidson created the vacancy by quitting in August, it would seem forward planning is not Ms Brsquos strong point.Odd businessALSO appearing to have trouble on that front is her Tory colleague Alexander Burnett, the minted MSP for Aberdeenshire West. One of his many money spinners is facing a statutory fine for failing to file timely accounts at Companies House. The North Banchory Company Ltd, in which Mr Burnett, holds all poundm worth of shares, should have filed last month. It also failed to file accounts on time in . Mr Burnett is - you guessed it - his partyrsquos spokesman on business.Total bankersMUCH sniggering at the back in Holyrood during Tuesdayrsquos vote to create a new Scottish National Investment Bank. Scottish Labour leader Richard Leonard opined that hersquod had the same brilliant idea  years ago, only the SNPrsquos version was not bold and ambitious enough. ldquoThere is too much of an air of tame mediocrity about it, when what we need is courage and ambition, he snfed. Well, takes one to know one.Mountain eruptsDECIDEDLY fewer smiles two days later at FMQs, as Nat Stuart McMillan used his question to attack Tory MSP Sir Edward Mountain. It followed Sir Ed asking shipping expertsa South Korean firm could have built two CalMac boats quicker than a Scottish yard which tried and failed big-time, costing taxpayers and extra poundm. Mr McMillan implied it was unpatriotic of Sir Ed, who furiously rumbled and fumed in his seat nearby. He has been renamed Mr Volcano.Close watchTHE Politico website has just published a list of the ldquo MPs to watch in . Scotland gets a couple of mentions. Swinson slayer Amy Callaghan is ldquomarked out by SNP leader Nicola Sturgeon as a rising star apparently. Also namechecked is former Justice Secretary Kenny MacAskill. Westminster Nats could ldquobenefit from his long memory, it says. However the SNP has never been short of long memories. Ms Sturgeon and chums will never forget him for recently putting the odds of Indyref soon at lsquolikely nil, for instance.Luncheon meetHOLYROODrsquoS press pack jetted off to Brussels this week to mark the final countdown to Brexit. Hacks used the opportunity to quiz tight-lipped EU officials on the prospects of an independent Scotland rejoining the bloc. ldquoOne final technical point just on Scotlandrsquos re-entry, a journalist piped up at the end of an interminable lunch, at which the issue was raised repeatedly. ldquoYoursquoll be back by the time this lunch is over, a weary official shot back.

title: plans-unveiled-radical-revamp-paisley-town-centre
story: Now plans have been unveiled to transform Paisley town centre by breathing fresh le into its streets and bringing empty shops back into use.A new study by Glasgow-based Threesixty Architecture lays out a series of radical ideas for how the town can be ldquorebalanced for the future.Colourful artistrsquos impressions show a widened high street bustling with le, outlining how the area could look in ten yearsrsquo time ndash albeit with an optimistic view of Scottish weather.Suggestions for the townrsquos revamp include repurposing the Paisley Centre shopping hub into a new residential quarter with ground-floor retail, as well as introducing a European-style food hall housing independent bars and eateries.Public spaces for outdoor activity could also be introduced, alongside lanes and streets creating new views and routes to lsquohiddenrsquo parts of the town centre.Meanwhile, vacant historic buildings such as the Liberal Club, YMCA building and TA Building could be brought back into use, and a high street cinema opened to attract visitors.Parts of university and college campuses could also be relocated into the heart of the town centre.SNP Communities Secretary Aileen Campbell said the study ldquorepresents another signicant milestone in the regeneration of Paisley and is further evidence of the ambition and commitment of the local community and partners.She said: ldquoA huge opportunity now exists to use this collaborative vision to create more positive change in the town, as well as sharing learning which can benefit other town centres and communities across Scotland.The lsquoVision for Paisley Town Centre rsquo study is the result of a unique collaboration between Renfrewshire Council, the Scottish Government and Scotlandrsquos Town Partnership, and uses Paisley as a test case for a series of bold ideas which could also be implemented where.It aims to build on the momentum created by the townrsquos unsuccessful bid to become UK City of Culture .This includes a pound million investment in its venues and outdoor spaces, including turning Paisley Museum into a world-class destination.Renfrewshire Council leader Iain Nicolson said towns everywhere are struggling with the same issues around empty retail spaces.He said: ldquoWe canrsquot turn the clock back but we can consider how we could change to attract new le and footfall in future ndash and thatrsquos what Paisley is doing.ldquoItrsquos important to stress these are not concrete plans ndash they are a set of ideas designed to spark a conversation about what might be possible over the next decade.ldquoPaisley town centre is already changing for the better ndash the number of new cafes and restaurants and new housing built in recent years shows it is recognised as a good place to live and invest.ldquoCurrent and future council investment will make Paisley even more attractive to the private sector, but change of the scale imagined by the Vision could not be achieved by the council alone ndash so we want to hear from developers who could make that next stage of the journey happen.Phil Prentice, chief officer of Scotlandrsquos Towns Partnership, added: ldquoPaisley has a rich tapestry of heritage and culture, is steeped in industry and tradition, and has many major assets.ldquoWe hope this exciting blueprint can create a high street fit for st century citizens and Paisley can become an exemplar for other large towns across Scotland.Alan Anthony, managing director of Threesixty Architecture, who authored the new study, said it showed ldquoa people-first approach that reconnects the whole community to their town centre.He said: ldquoAs a lelong Paisley Buddy, itrsquos exciting to think Paisley could lead the way on town centre regeneration in Scotland.Gary Kerr, chair of the Paisley Community Trust, said it fully backed the plans.He said: ldquoItrsquos particularly encouraging to see cinema at the forefront of the vision.ldquoThis completely aligns with our current plans to bring cinema back to the heart of our town.ldquoWe believe a cinema by and for our community is a vital first step in realising the wider vision for regeneration in the town centre.

title: tom-gordon-nicola-sturgeons-next-steps-put-judgment-line
story: It will no longer be enough to huff and puff about Boris Johnson.Very soon she will have to switch on the government and legislative machinery required for a vote she surely knows isnrsquot coming.Campaign organisations would have to be created, rules drawn up, the question tested, ing officers and the police put on notice.Complaining about the Prime Ministerrsquos refusal to give Holyrood the power to hold a legal referendum would not advance the charade.Crucially,Ms Sturgeon intends to stick to her line of Indyref in late , she will have to start spending large amounts of public money.To do so on a cynical stunt would invite a backlash from the electorate.Voters arenrsquot impressed by their taxes being spent for performative reasons, or as part of blatant SNP electioneering for .Printing and distributing the independence White Paper of  cost pound.m alone, for instance.:Iain Macwhirter: In post-Brexit Britain, Nicola Sturgeon cant keep telling her troops that Indyref is round the corner. It isntNor would they be impressed by Ms Sturgeon pressing on out of petulance, naivete or deluded egotism.We will know more when the First Minister updates Holyrood on her ldquonext steps on Wednesday.It will be a big moment. It will, above all, be a test of her judgment.If she persists in the fiction that she can have Indyref this year, her reputation may never recover.You can see why itrsquos hard to admit the gamersquos a bogie though.Besides letting down the SNP members she has marched up so many hills, Ms Sturgeon said a vote for the SNP last month would stop Brexit, stop Boris, and deliver Indyref.The first and second didnrsquot pan out, leaving her clinging to the third.If she gives up on that too, itrsquos three strikes. Not a good look for a leader under daily attack for over-promising and under-delivering in government.But a wistful climbdown is surely better than a damaging pantomime.After all, when she hit pause on independence for two years after the  snap election, she ultimately went on to greater success.Itrsquos hard to see who Ms Sturgeon could even convince. Not even SNP HQ appears to believe her timetable.Last week a number of former party luminaries said the Yes movement needed a new campaign vehicle, something like Yes Scotland in .But while the legal entity behind Better Together was dissolved after the No vote, Yes Scotland actually lives on, maintained in a state of suspended animation at Companies House by the SNPrsquos in-house solicitor.It could be cranked back to lewanted. Instead, it gathers dust.Then there are the campaign website names the SNP bought on the back of the Brexit referendum.You may remember the party launched a poundm fundraiser through the ref.scot website after Ms Sturgeon first announced in March  that she intended to hold Indyref.It has since fallen into disuse.The SNP also bought mobilise.scot and organise.scot as part of its push.The ownership has been allowed to lapse and both are up for sale again.Nor is there a refreshed case for independence, and time is flying by.The SNP has yet to prepare public opinion for its new position on adopting a Scottish currency as soon as practicable after independence.It has not said how it would respond to Brexit, particularly how it would handle trade and customs arrangements with Englandit was out of the EU and Scotland rejoined.ldquoIf we go into a referendum offering a hard border at Gretna wersquore f***ed, as one SNP MSP puts it.:Nicola Sturgeon: Scotland redefining what it means to be successful nationIndeed, itrsquos hard to see how anyone could offer such plans until we know what Brexit looks like - after the UK-EU trade talks this year.Then there is White Paper .It was reported yesterday that Ms Sturgeonrsquos officials continue to revise the slab-like prospectus of  to ensure Scots can make ldquoan informed choice over the future of our country.The Tories were duly outraged at this, given Mr Johnsonrsquos rejection of referendum powers for Holyrood.I was not at all outraged. As independence is the governmentrsquos avowed policy, it is natural for it to task civil servants with developing that policy. But where is it The original White Paper was published almost  days before the  referendum to give voters time to study its  pages.As Ms Sturgeon holds up that referendum as the ldquogold standard template for the next one, it would seem White Paper  is already late.Agreed, there are  days left in . But December and November arenrsquot candidates for Indyref because of Christmas and the massive COP climate conference in Glasgow draining police resources.The last practical date would be October, and that means there is already less time to study any new White Paper than last time.Yet the Scottish Government said only this week, in response to a freedom of information request, that it would be updating the White Paper ldquoover the next few months.Soit ever does emerge, there may be only half the time of  to come to ldquoan informed choice, plus it would be full of holes about Brexit.It would hardly be an advert for efficient, joyous government outside the Union - and thatrsquos before the stooshie about the bill for printing it and getting it to every household.Ms Sturgeon would be accused of taunting taxpayers with their own cash, sending them a non-prospectus for a non-referendum.The First Minister is a formidable politician. Her opponents may criticise her record and goals, but they respect and envy her ability.They would not characterise her as slapdash or unprofessional.Butshe were to blow millions on a rush-job White Paper without a legal referendum in sight, or play to impatient Yessers by attempting a hillbilly referendum of her own, that respect would be lost overnight.She would be damned as cavalier, a loose cannon not to be trusted with devolution far less independence.Ms Sturgeon wonrsquot like it, but her choice is between retreat now with dignity or retreat later without it.

title: volunteers-needed-build-17th-century-house-glencoe
story: The National Trust for Scotlandis offering those with an interest in the past an opportunity to build a replica house fit for a th-century crofter ndash complete with turf roof and wattle and daub walls.The project is part of a push to explore the story of Glen Coe and find the ldquolost villages which vanished from the map in the aftermath of the infamous massacre of .Volunteers will help create the type of dwelling used by the glenrsquos inhabitants on the eve of the attack by government soldiers, which led to the deaths of around  men, women and children.Many of the buildings were put to the torch while livestock were driven off, and settlements which had stood for centuries disappeared from the map.Now a new ldquoturfhouse, which would have been familiar to those departed villagers, will rise again in the grounds of the Glencoe Visitor Centre, which reopened last year after a major refurbishment.Glencoe Operations Manager Emily BryceGlencoe Operations Manager Emily Bryce said: ldquoItrsquos nearly a year since we revamped our Glencoe visitor centre and this project, with the support of public donations, is our next step in sharing the story of this incredible landscape which we are so proud to protect.ldquoItrsquos very exciting that wersquoll be able to involve the public and visitors in such a hands-on way. Wersquoll also be working with our local community and schools too, and are keen to make sure that the whole area benefits from this project.Glen Coe was the scene of one of the clan erarsquos most notorious episodes in Scottish history, when the British state conspired with local chiefs to attack the MacDonald clan who called the glen their home over their failure to pledge allegiance to King William III in time.Soldiers from the Earl of Argyllrsquos regiment, who had been staying in the glen and enjoying the famous Highland hospitality of its inhabitants, suddenly turned on their hosts on the morning of February , .Dozens were slaughtered while many more were driven over the bleak hills in the dead of winter, where they died from exposure as they fled ill-clothed and unprepared.In the years that followed the area was largely given over to sheep farming, with the remaining inhabitants forced to move where.The Trust has been investigating three villages which were abandoned during that time ndash Inverigan, Achnacon and Achtriochtan ndash and the reconstructed turfhouse will be used to highlight the way their inhabitants lived, more than  years ago.Archaeologists have been excavating in GlencoeHolidaymakers who help build the structure will get the chance to work in a wide iety of tasks, including whittling wooden pegs to weaving wattle walls, archaeological excavations and mud daubing.To oversee the project, NTS has recruited a team with vast experience in traditional building methods, while archaeologists who have explored the area will work on the buildingrsquos design.These specialists in turf-building, heather thatching, wattle and daub, timber creel and cruck frame structures will lead trainees and volunteers over the course of the year in the unique experiment in historical reconstruction.The project is being made possible thanks to members of the public from around the world who donated to a fundraising appeal last year.In  the conservation charity that protects Scotlandrsquos national and natural treasures invested over poundm in Glencoe Visitor Centre, transforming the existing eco-friendly buildings into a more modern, immersive and welcoming ldquogateway to the world-renowned glen.The visitor centre has a  seat film screening space showing a specially-commissioned film which takes viewers on a -minute journey from the glenrsquos volcanic origins and its tragic past, while also examining its enduring popularity with tourists and outdoor enthusiasts.A large D map and an Info Hub was also installed to help visitors plan their adventures and share advice on how to explore the area responsibly.The Glencoe Visitor Centre also plays an essential part in generating income to support the NTSrsquos conservation work in Glencoe National Nature Reserve, where it oversees the protection of more than , acres of wilderness, including km of footpaths and eight Munros.

title: fidelma-cook-got-english-casual-arrogant-ignorance
story: She doubted many things in her ordinary, extraordinary le her middle years spent in England like many of her country women but she never doubted her right to live in a free Ireland.Born into a Republican family she was reared on the injustices meted out to her poor country as her own le weathered servitude, poverty, sickness and all the tragedies that make up a personal history.At the same time, Irsquom reading Victoria Hisloprsquos lsquoThose Who Are Loved,rsquo a family saga set against the backdrop of wartime occupation in Greece and the subsequent civil war.The two books couldnrsquot be more dferent in setting and pace and yet so alike in the fierceness of the determination of the two central women to set their countries free.One grew up in the Irish Free State, where homes were still ided in the bitter aftermath of the civil war, and the country lanes were dotted with hand spun memorials to the fallen and the murdered.The other fought with the Communists against foes who were once allies, and at warrsquos end, like so many, was tracked down, captured, re-educated by torture ndash by her own people whorsquod learned well at the hands of the fascists.One book a biography, the other a novel. One woman real, the other a beautully drawn imaginary portrait.Laying down the books what stayed with me was the essence, the spirit of both, and the feeling that one had grasped the mood of both countries.I know one country well, the other not at all. I know France well, or so I think, and certainly have grasped both history and mood all the more for living here.When I write about two of the three countries mentioned, I do so with the confidence of close contact of stories told and remembered of links forged republic to republic.I do the same with England and Scotland although I havenrsquot set foot in either for years. But I lived and worked in both. I switched listening modes from London to Glasgow as easily as switching TV channels and in Scotland reported on and witnessed a country rapidly evolving, gathering within it a fresh pride, a steely core to rid itself of dependence on Westminster. A desire ndash long before the words were so grotesquely appropriated by the Brexiters ndash to take back control.I lsquogotrsquo it. And I lsquogotrsquo the English too in their casual, arrogant ignorance and lack of interest in anything other than them.I got it having grown up in a country which also was powering towards a new destiny remembering the past but not in thrall to it looking forward to Europe and not back to the chains of an inglorious Empire.So, when I comment, I comment from a little knowledge, from a tapping in to, not just the history, but the spirit.It is why I am constantly surprised by commentators who pronounce on Scotland, on referendums and on the Party, which is the driving force for Independence.Many words are expended on reasons why that should not be, using suspect financial lsquofactsrsquo and endless repetition of half, long negated arguments that research would have knocked down immediately.Some of the arguments against Scotland leaving the Union are well-reasoned and well worth consideration but these too are knocked down by the lamentable chippiness of some who are as blind as the commentators they dismiss.Itrsquos a word blindness activated by what is seen as a malevolent force robbing and battering the Scots from time immemorial. That is not the truth but there is a truth contained within it.What irritates me above all in most of these comment pieces coming from over the Border, is absence, awareness. Absence of any attempt to delve under the demands to seek the almost indefinable ndash the spirit of a people.Any reading of history shows that movements grow slowly until suddenly, like a high tide, they gather and form until the point they are unstoppable.Sometimes though the expected tide doesnrsquot reach its watermark and flops against the bulwarks ndash becalmed, almost shocked at its sudden halt.If not careful, the Independence movement could reach that point and make no mistake, nothing is being spared by the Westminster Opposition to ensure it does.Confidence can be chipped away statistics twisted to enable doubt to take seed groups encouraged to agitate from within with public spats that only increase the nervousness of those unsure and uncertainthey want to leave the familiar.Cynicism in these times is good ndash but not too much. Passion is good ndash but must be controlled. Anger is good ndash but swallow pride and turn it outwards not back into the group.Much is made of Irelandrsquos struggle for independence and its success on the European stage. Some believe a whole nation rose up. In fact, the Easter rising was begun by a handful, ridiculed by Dubliners as they marched to the Four Courts.Captured, they could have gone down as yet another minor episode. But the British made a mistake and murdered them in Kilmainham Gaol, creating heroes and firing up the land.The British always make a mistake because they never understand the soul of a country.Patience.

title: herald-diary-bawdy-beautiful
story: IT being Burns Night this evening, we would be remisswe didnrsquot celebrate the bonnie, bawdy Bard of Ayrshire on this page. With that thought in mind, wersquove hunted through the Diaryrsquos vault and discovered some classic tales which we think Rabbie would have approved of. In other words, wersquove collected a bunch of rude, crude and occasionally booze-infused yarns for your predilection. For instance, an eagle-eyed Diary reader once spotted that the author of the American edition of a book called the Illustrated Encyclopaedia of Sex was called Dr A Willy.Tatty-bye teethA TALE from the Hebrides of a non-fisherman invited for a wee trip on a boat out to gather the catch from some lobster creels. The guest was feeling queasy because of the slight swell, although a recent dalliance with the drink couldnrsquot be ruled out as a factor.As he was watching the lobster fishermen at work, said chap was overcome and was sick over the side, losing his  teeth in the process. This caused much hilarity among the crew, who decided to prolong the fun.They borrowed the skipperrsquos  teeth and placed them in a creel as it was brought on deck. What a miracle, they explained. What a chance in a million for the sea to yield up the dentures which had been so cruelly lost. The victim of their hoax was quite amazed and put in the said  teeth. But they remained in his mouth only a few seconds. ldquoAch, these arenrsquot my teeth, he grumbled as he pulled out the skipperrsquos dentures and tossed them into the sea.Dodgy docLIKE Burns, Chic Murray was a genius of a very Scottish sort, whose material was sometimes a smidgen saucy. The Diary has always been a collector of his most memorable musings, such as his recollection of visiting his local GP. ldquoStrip, said the doctor. ldquoWhere will I hang my clothes  asked Chic. ldquoJust put them on top of mine, replied the doctor.Fruity funA GROUP of high-spirited nurses were given a guided tour of a Glasgow fire station where part of the tour featured a demonstration of the infrared thermal imaging camera, used to detect hot-spots in smoke-filled buildings. The firefighters thought it would be funny to heat up a few large bananas in a microwave oven and conceal them in their waterproofs shortly before the demonstration took place. One by one the nurses took a long, meaningful squint through the camerarsquos eye piece before silently handing it over to the next colleague in line. Needless to say, the chaps didnrsquot crack on about their prank, and were very soon afterwards inundated with requests for the tour to become a regular feature on the nursesrsquo social calendar.A corkerWE were once told of a young lady who had a very informative nickname. Her pals called her Genie. Apparentlyyou pulled a cork out of a bottle she would be at your side in seconds.Rabbie on tourA WELL-KNOWN Scottish tenor who had attended Burns suppers in the exotic climes of Egypt informed usthat the locals had their own name for todayrsquos celebration ndash itrsquos known as The Feast of Ramadram.Read more: Address to a dim sum

title: kevin-mckenna-football-must-stop-betting-firms-preying-fans
story: If you doubt this then you havenrsquot experienced the rush of watching a horse bearing its rider ndash and your modest outlay ndash down the final strait at the head of a chase. Or seeing your chosen football team for the day defending your stake as though their lives depended on it.On these occasions, any losses are the affordable cost, happily borne, of momentarily living le a little more jaggy.Most of us who have ever placed a wager know the odds of sustained success are stacked against us from the outset but itrsquos a deal wersquove struck with our eyes open. We have been fortunate that any wrong turning wersquove made in our lives any adversity, hasnrsquot yet left us prey to addiction.Digital technology increases in sophistication with each passing year. Those who can harness it quickly discover that it can be turned into sharp profit without meddlesome factors like human labour, factory costs and a care for the environment. This has transformed the act of placing a bet on a sporting outcome.:Brian Rice case highlight how approach to gambling in Scottish football has to be revisitedPreviously, the issues associated with addiction and problem gambling were unintended and unsought. Irsquom not saying here you could ever have characterised this industry by its empathy for the flawed human condition. Once, there had been a degree of humanity though, where checks and balances might be provided simply by visiting a bookmakers and interacting with friends and neighbours.Now, billions are spent by the online gambling industry to ensure that addiction isnrsquot an unfortunate consequence but a desired outcome. And professional football, the most popular sport in the world, is where the lowest-hanging fruit is to be found.This week, Brian Rice, the respected manager of Hamilton Academical FC, became the latest high-profile football person to admit that he has been struggling with gambling addiction for most of his adult le.His story is only the latest in a long litany of human tragedies associated with football and gambling.Almost immediately the football tribe ndash managers, players and journalists ndash threw a protective cordon around him and praised Mr Rice for his dignity and courage in going public with his ordeal. Predictably, they strove to absolve the football authorities and our major clubs from any blame that might have attached to them owing to their lucrative association with online gambling.Some of their arguments were reasonable.After all, much of the sponsorship cash can be spent on developing young players and supporting nearby health and wellbeing initiatives in local communities.This though, is a bit like saying thatyou swim with sharks it can give you a greaterappreciation of their natural environment.  There is a reason why the predatory giants of the online gambling industry have targeted professional football. In no other sphere of human endeavour do so many working-class people gather in such huge numbers at regular intervals.According to recently reported research the industry is using third-party companies to collect personal data and thus enable online casinos to target low-income customers and ex-gamblers. One former digital marketing specialist in the industry said: ldquoThird-party data providers allowed us to target their email lists with precision. Lower-income users were among the most successfully targeted segments.The eye-watering profits accruing from gambling allow operators to use every artice and lever at their disposal to ensure they are ring-fenced. In the House of Commons several MPs recently sought to defend fixed-odds betting machines , the so-called ldquocrack cocaine of gambling in the face of Government proposals to limit them. These politicians were later revealed to have received expensive gts and hospitality from the betting industry.:Neil Cameron: Brian Rice case nothing to do with hypocrisySo vast and pernicious is the influence of the gambling lobby that in , the former Sports Minister, Tracey Crouch, was forced to admit defeat. She resigned after the government refused to back down on the timetable for reducing the maximum stake on FOBMs. She had wanted the change to be made earlier than the planned date of October . Yet senior colleagues ignored her even when she said that the delay could lead to hundreds of people killing themselves because of gambling addiction linked to these machines.Ms Crouch wasnrsquot indulging in emotional hyperbole here. In , research published in the journal Neuron, found that gambling makes people susceptible to depression and anxiety by altering the brainrsquos physical structure. Previous research had consistently found links associating gambling with debt, family breakdown and a suite of mental health issues.The new research though, found thatthese affective disorders diminish the capacity to tolerate economic risk.The online behemoths prey on menwhen they are at their most vulnerable. This is when they are watching live football and drinking.Their smartphone devices are weaponised by the online companies to extract as much money as possible from them in the two-hour window available to them.Odds are offered on every twist and turn of the action by a bewildering array of online products that bookend the televised pictures and analysis. The Gambling Commission recently fined a major online firm poundm after it missed more than  incidents indicating behaviour associated with a problem gambler. On one occasion the gambler immediately re-staked substantial winnings, suggesting this was either a money-laundering operation or an affluent addict. Yet this occurs much more often further down the financial scale but escapes scrutiny owing to the smaller sums.The football authorities which solicit these firms and the clubs who prostitute themselves to them are just as culpable in spreading the disease of gambling addiction. They are knowingly giving licence to these companies to destroy the lives of their most vulnerable and disadvantaged supporters.My own team, Celtic, have won more trophies than I could ever have hoped for during my letime. Yet I would gladly trade all of them to redeem the le of one person and their family ruined by addiction to gambling. And I would beseech Celtic and all other clubs who permit their colours to be contaminated by the logos of these online jackals to be rid of them and to work harder to attract more ethical and less-lethal sponsorship.

title: glasgow-city-council-write-prime-minister-scottish-independence
story: The invitation was made during a debate on Scottish Independence at Thursdays full council meeting.During the discussion  councillors agreed that the local authority would write to Boris Johnson to demand that it should be up to the Scottish Government to determine another referendum.Councillor Susan Aitken also accused the Conservatives of taking on the role of a pantomime villain during the debate.:Tom Gordon: Nicola Sturgeonrsquos lsquonext stepsrsquo put her judgment on the lineLabour and Tory councillors argued that a "once in a letime vote" meant that and not every seven years and that the SNP should "get back to the day job".Councillor Euan Blockley said: "I am not only upset and angry having to debate this in this chamber - thats  minutes of my le that Im not going to get back - but there are so many more things that this council should be focussing on."We have an education system in this country that is in a dire state of affairs. We have ahealthsystem in crisis, with a hospital in Glasgow which has children dying of preventable diseases because of bird droppings."We have a drug epidemic in this city - the worst in Europe. The SNP would rather discuss their pet project. The people in Glasgow are sick and tired of this nonsense."You are having a giraffe. You said once in a generation - once in a letime. Drop this tripe and get on with the day job."Labour councillor Archie Graham also agreed that "once in a letime does not mean a vote every six or seven years."He added: "Once in a generation is not even once every six or seven years. Might this motion be here to deflect from the miserable record of the SNP administration in Glasgow and the SNP Scottish Government in Holyrood."There are missed bin collections, potholes by the hundreds, the shambles of the communities fund and redundancy notices being sent out to third sector staff are the issues that are being raised with us at this present time by our constituents not demands for another referendum."Tens of millions of pounds more in cuts to services are faced by us in the coming financial year. Let us join together in arguing for resources for this great city rather than engage in neverending discussion about the referendum.":Letters: We may yet be forced into an unofficial referendumCouncillor Susan Aitken said that opposition parties should stop "diminishing" the role of the council.Ms Aitken said: "The Conservatives seem to like to behave like pantomime villains in this chamber. It is possible to do more than one thing at once. By all means challenge us where services are not reaching that standards that we want either."Every time you define our day job as something so narrow - you diminish this city and you diminish our role as councillors."

story: The first Citizens Advice Bureaux were set up  years ago, to help people during World War Two.Issues back then ranged from ration books to evacuations from homes and missing people.There are now  CABs theand breadth of the country, which are overseen by Citizens Advice Scotland .While the issues have evolved over the years, their remit has remained the same: to provide free, independent advice in complete confidence.Derek Mitchell, CAS chief executive officer, said: â€œWe are the biggest independent provider of free advice in Scotland.â€œOur CABs offer a one-stop shop to help people solve their problems.â€œSomeone can come in about their energy bills but we discover they have an average of seven dferent issues in their lives.â€œWhen youâ€™re living on a budget and your washing machine breaks down, you have to make a choice to fix it and send your children to school with clean clothes or to pay your rent.â€œMaking that choice can result in more debt.â€œThatâ€™s when our service really comes into its own.â€And thereâ€™s little doubt that the advice service works CABs have dealt with , advice issues in the last year and helped more than , Scots.Last year, they secured Â£ million for the , people who made contact â€“ money which has helped not only those seeking advice, but the communities in which they live.Derek said: â€œI think our trust rating speaks for itself:  per cent of people who have used our service would recommend us to a friend or relative.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! which is spent in local communities which are also struggling.â€œFor every pound invested in our services, we provide a minimum of Â£ .â€CAS also invests in people, with some  volunteers across Scotland helping staff to provide services.â€œOur unpaid advisers are very, very good at what they do,â€ said Derek.â€œAnd something that isnâ€™t widely known, but should be celebrated, is the fact that  per cent of them go on to paid employment or further education.â€œI donâ€™t know of any other organisation in Scotland that can claim such ain investing in its people.â€Whether paid staff or volunteers, there are four main issues every CAB deals with on a daily basis â€“ debts, benefits, employment and housing.The Scottish and UK governments have provided funding to allow CAS to provide services, including Help to Claim, Financial Health Check and, more recently, EU Settlement.These national services operate across Scotland and help supplement funding from local authorities for CAB services.Derek said: â€œHelp to Claim was introduced to help clients claim Universal Credit, which a lot of people were having dficulty with.â€œThe Financial Health Check can be accessed over the phone or in person at Citizens Advice Bureaux.â€œItâ€™s just a chat to see what you might be entitled to and advice to help make the most of your money.â€œAnd more than , people in Scotland have applied to the EU Settlement scheme, seeking leave to remain here after Brexit.â€œThe service offers free assistance to any EU, EEA or Swiss person who wants to stay here.â€œWe have helped many of these people through the process we think there may be many more who would like to apply but donâ€™t know how to go about it.â€Despite all its good work, Derek believes the need for the advice service is only likely to grow, with an uncertain future facing many families and iniduals in Scotland.He explained: â€œIn terms of political and economic uncertainty, le for many people we see is going to get worse rather than better.â€œBut we have been here for  years and people should know weâ€™ll continue to be here for them, should they need our support.â€œFrom  to today, we have been there to give people who are marginalised in our communities a voice.â€œWe use the information we glean from our clients to advocate for them on a national .â€œIf people are coming in to our CAB offices across Scotland and raising the same issue, we can pull that information together and say to the Scottish and UK governments there is an issue we need to solve. â€œThatâ€™s quite a powerful tool which helps to give people a hand up, rather than a hand out.â€That tool was used to good effect to ensure Universal Credit claimants no longer had to phone a premium rate number to lodge claims.However, there is much more yet to be done.â€œBringing seven benefits into one in theory is fine but in practice it made it much more dficult for people,â€ said Derek.â€œHaving to phone a premium number for around  minutes was costing people Â£ or more so we lobbied and the premium number no longer exists.â€œBut the five-week wait for benefits is still a major issue and we will continue to campaign on that issue.â€œWe were at the forefront of calling for changes, long before anyone  in Scotland, and we will continue to do so.â€In its th year, CAS has had much to celebrate with patron, Princess Anne, being at the centre of celebrations â€“ spending three hours speaking to volunteers.A debate in the Scottish Parliament ran for an hour as so many politicians wanted to share their experiences of the service.And during the general election in December, every political leader praised the work that CABs do.Derek is proud that the charity has stood the test of time and believes it will still be going strong in another  yearsâ€™ time.However, his last word of thanks was to the volunteers who help run the service.â€œWe would not be hereit wasnâ€™t for the volunteers who give of their time freely,â€ he added, â€œthey are the bedrock of our service.â€œWhat they do, day in and day out, across the country is invaluable. â€œWe couldnâ€™t open the doors without them and they are vital to our future.â€For more information on services across Scotland, visit www.citizensadvice.org.uk scotland.History of Citizens Advice Scotland, from  to -: The first CABs were busy tracing missing people, arranging evacuations and helping with war damage claims. Rationing also generated thousands of enquiries, and bureaux persuaded the government to grant extra clothes coupons to pregnant women. The first CABs in  were in Glasgow, Aberdeen, Stirling and Dundee.Post-war period: Against expectations, the end of the war brought an increased demand. CABs dealt with more enquiries than at the height of the blitz. Housing problems and family breakdowns increased. To meet this demand, the number of CABs began to prolerate.The advent of Legal Aid and the NHS led to a surge in enquiries.s: Housing problems continued to grow as people struggled with the housing shortage, overcrowding, and the end of rent controls.Hire purchase promised le on the â€˜never-never.â€™ For many this led to mounting debts.s: Rents were rocketing, yet many people were still living in slum conditions and homelessness was rising. By  housing problems accounted for a quarter of the . million problems dealt with by CABs across the UK.Divorce reform too led to a surge in enquiries, with family problems representing  per cent of the CAB workload.s: Family, housing and benefit problems remained the top priority, but the consumer boom saw personal debt soar too. Industrial change saw an increase in redundancies and workersâ€™ rights issues.s: Consumerism brought with it two recessions and debt and benefit cases doubled. Employment enquiries rose by  per cent. But debt, stemming from easy credit, became the biggest CAB issue.s: Social security became the top issue and sharp rises in VAT didnâ€™t help. Repossessions and homelessness increased.-: Payday loans, combined with a lack of affordable housing, caused unprecedented levels of debt. Welfare reform left many families in debt, with Universal Credit generating enormous numbers of enquiries.
